item.title: PCOS on a Budget
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded:
Hey love ‚Äî I‚Äôm Jackie Fryndej-Cruz, Functional Nutrition Coach, hormone health educator, and your guide through this journey to hormone harmony, food freedom, and maybe even a baby (if that‚Äôs your goal). I created this guide because I know firsthand how confusing, overwhelming, and expensive healing can feel ‚Äî especially when you‚Äôre dealing with PCOS, irregular cycles, fertility struggles, or that exhausting "why won‚Äôt my body just cooperate?" energy. Here‚Äôs the thing: healing your hormones doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect. It doesn‚Äôt have to be expensive. And it sure as hell doesn‚Äôt have to be boring. What it does need to be is real, rooted in what works, and designed to fit your life ‚Äî not take it over. That‚Äôs what this guide is about. Whether you‚Äôre here to support your cycle, prep your body for pregnancy, or just feel like yourself again, you‚Äôre in the right place. This isn‚Äôt about restriction ‚Äî it‚Äôs about reclaiming your rhythm. Let‚Äôs get you nourished, educated, and empowered ‚Äî with plenty of flavor, flexibility, and a little bit of fun (because hormones don‚Äôt have to be so serious all the time). I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôre here. Let‚Äôs do this together. üíõ

üí∏ Introduction: PCOS is Costly, But Healing Doesn‚Äôt Have to Be

Hey girl. Let‚Äôs get one thing straight: you shouldn‚Äôt have to choose between healing your hormones and paying your rent. PCOS already comes with enough baggage ‚Äî irregular periods, mood swings, breakouts, exhaustion, bloating, and the anxiety spiral of Googling ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs wrong with me‚Äù at 2 a.m. Add on the pressure to eat perfectly, take expensive supplements, see multiple specialists, and completely overhaul your life overnight? Overwhelming. Expensive. And honestly? Unfair. But here‚Äôs the truth nobody‚Äôs telling you: you can start healing without draining your bank account. You don‚Äôt need expensive lab panels, overpriced green powders, or a fridge full of organic superfoods. You need strategy. Simplicity. A little sass. And someone to cut through the BS. That‚Äôs what this guide is here for.

üí° The Real Talk on Healing PCOS

PCOS is a complex, root-cause condition ‚Äî which means you can‚Äôt slap a bandage on the symptoms and expect long-term results. Healing takes time, consistency, and support ‚Äî but it doesn‚Äôt require you to go broke in the process. Here‚Äôs the good news:
  • Blood sugar balance? Free.
  • Walking and sunlight? Free.
  • Nervous system regulation? Free.
  • Eating strategically with basic grocery staples? Way cheaper than takeout.
The most powerful healing tools? They're not found in a supplement bottle or trendy wellness ad. They're found in your kitchen, your daily routine, and how you choose to show up for your body every day.

üß† What You‚Äôll Learn in This Guide

This guide is your roadmap for smart, affordable, real-life hormone healing. We‚Äôll cover:
  • How to grocery shop like a PCOS queen without the Whole Foods price tag
  • The supplements that actually matter ‚Äî and the ones you can skip
  • Free healing habits that support your hormones, gut, and mood
  • A sample PCOS-friendly meal plan that won‚Äôt break the bank
  • A breakdown of what healing really looks like when you're doing it on a budget
This isn‚Äôt a detox. This isn‚Äôt a diet. This is a realistic path to balance for women who are tired of being tired ‚Äî and tired of being told it‚Äôs all in their head. You don‚Äôt need to be perfect. You don‚Äôt need to be rich. You just need to be ready. Ready to eat better without the overwhelm. Ready to listen to your body without the judgment. Ready to show up ‚Äî for your healing, for your hormones, and for yourself. Let‚Äôs get into it. üíõ

item.title: The Testosterone Tune-Up
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded: üëã Welcome to The Testosterone Tune-Up Hey, I‚Äôm Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz, Functional Nutrition Counselor, hormone health educator, and founder of House of Jay. And I‚Äôm really glad you‚Äôre here. If you picked up this guide, chances are something feels off. Maybe it‚Äôs your energy. Maybe it‚Äôs your focus, your mood, or your drive ‚Äî and no one‚Äôs been able to give you a straight answer. You‚Äôre not alone ‚Äî and you‚Äôre not broken. The truth is, testosterone plays a far bigger role in your health than most people realize. It‚Äôs not just about the gym or the bedroom. It‚Äôs about how you wake up. How you recover. How you show up in your life. This course is here to help you understand what testosterone really does, why it might be running low, and ‚Äî most importantly ‚Äî how to support it naturally from the inside out. I‚Äôm not here to sell you a magic pill. I‚Äôm here to walk you through the foundations: sleep, stress, nutrition, movement, and mindset. This is a full-body tune-up for men who want to feel powerful, steady, and clear again. You don‚Äôt need to be a bodybuilder or biohacker to take back your health. You just need to start. And that‚Äôs exactly what we‚Äôre going to do ‚Äî step by step, with real tools, real science, and real support. Let‚Äôs get into it. ‚Äî Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz Functional Nutrition & Integrative Wellness Practitioner HouseofJay.net | HouseofJay@writeme.com

item.title: üéóÔ∏è Holding Space: How to Support a Loved One Through Cancer Diagnosis & Treatment
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded:
¬†A heart-led, practical guide to showing up with compassion, presence, and purpose. üéóÔ∏è Welcome to Holding Space A Practical, Heart-Led Guide to Supporting a Loved One Through Cancer Hi love ‚Äî First, let me just say: I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôre here. If you‚Äôre reading this, it likely means someone you love has received a cancer diagnosis. And that moment ‚Äî whether it came as a quiet conversation, a rushed phone call, or a blur in a waiting room ‚Äî changed everything. You might be feeling overwhelmed. Unsure. Heartbroken. You might not know what to say, what to do, or how to help. But here‚Äôs the truth: the fact that you care enough to be here means you‚Äôre already showing up. And that matters more than you know. This guide wasn‚Äôt written to make you an expert. It‚Äôs not a checklist of ‚Äúright things‚Äù or a script to memorize. It‚Äôs a companion ‚Äî a steady voice in your ear reminding you that love doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect. It just has to be present.   In this course, we‚Äôll walk through:
  • How to ground yourself when emotions run high
  • What to say (and what to avoid) when words feel hard
  • The practical ways to help ‚Äî meals, rides, and care routines
  • How to stay present through treatment and uncertainty
  • What support looks like after the crisis phase ‚Äî when life keeps moving, but healing is still happening
You‚Äôll also find reminders, reflection prompts, and scripts you can use if you‚Äôre feeling stuck.   This is sacred work. You don‚Äôt have to fix it. You don‚Äôt have to carry it all. You just have to keep showing up ‚Äî with presence, patience, and love. I‚Äôm honored to walk with you through it. With care, Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz Functional Nutrition Coach

item.title: üß† First: Do You Need Supplements?
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Short answer? Not always. But can the right ones support your healing? Absolutely. The catch? You don‚Äôt need the ‚Äúinfluencer shelf‚Äù ‚Äî you need the essentials, based on what your body actually needs. Supplements should supplement a balanced foundation ‚Äî not replace food, sleep, or stress care. So let‚Äôs get into how to do this smart and on a budget. ‚úÖ Start with the Foundational 5 If you‚Äôre only going to spend money on a few things ‚Äî these are the ones that make the most bang-for-your-buck impact for PCOS:
  1. Magnesium (glycinate or citrate)
üí° Helps with: insulin resistance, sleep, mood, cravings, PMS üí∞ Affordable brands: NOW, Pure Encapsulations üíä Dosage: 300‚Äì400mg at night ‚ú® Bonus: You‚Äôll probably poop better too.  
  1. Vitamin D3 + K2
üí° Helps with: ovulation, immune regulation, hormone signaling üí∞ Tip: Get your levels tested ‚Äî most PCOS babes are low üíä Dosage: 2,000‚Äì5,000 IU daily with food + fat üåû If you‚Äôre on a tight budget ‚Äî sunshine is free. 15‚Äì20 minutes a day = magic.
  1. Omega-3 (EPA/DHA)
üí° Helps with: inflammation, egg quality, hormone production, period pain üí∞ Budget buy: Costco‚Äôs fish oil, or Barlean‚Äôs Omega Swirl (on sale!) üíä Dosage: 1,000‚Äì2,000 mg combined EPA/DHA üêü Can‚Äôt afford a supplement? Eat canned wild salmon or sardines 2x/week.
  1. Inositol (Myo or Myo + D-Chiro Blend)
üí° Helps with: insulin resistance, ovulation, egg quality üí∞ Budget brands: Wholesome Story (Amazon), BulkSupplements üíä Dosage: Myo-inositol 2g twice daily (or combo blend 40:1 ratio) üéØ Especially helpful if you have irregular periods or PCOS-related infertility.
  1. A Quality Multivitamin or Prenatal
üí° Helps with: filling nutritional gaps when food isn‚Äôt perfect üí∞ Look for: methylated B vitamins (folate > folic acid), no fillers üíä Brands under $30: Naturelo, SmartyPants, Seeking Health (often on sale) üõë Skip anything that says ‚ÄúOne-A-Day‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs underdosed and overhyped. ‚ùå What You Can (Probably) Skip Unless your practitioner specifically tells you to, you don‚Äôt need to drop $$$ on:
  • Supergreens powders
  • Collagen peptides (nice, not necessary)
  • DIM or estrogen blockers (can be too strong for self-dosing)
  • Berberine (unless you‚Äôre under supervision ‚Äî it‚Äôs potent)
  • Random hormone balancers with 15+ mystery herbs
‚ú® Reminder: More is not better. Targeted > trendy. üõçÔ∏è Where to Buy Supplements Without Spending a Fortune
Site Why We Love It
iHerb Frequent sales, bundle deals, low shipping
Amazon Wholesome Story, NOW, and other budget lines
Costco Great for omega-3s, magnesium, vitamin D
Vitacost Regular discounts and loyalty rewards
Local health stores Check clearance and ask for samples!
üí∏ The $50 Starter Stack (For Real Ones on a Budget) Here‚Äôs what to grab if you‚Äôre just starting out and want maximum impact with minimal spend:
Supplement Why It‚Äôs Worth It Est. Cost
Magnesium glycinate Sleep, stress, cravings, insulin $15
Inositol Ovulation, blood sugar, egg health $18
Vitamin D3 + K2 Hormone balance, mood, immune $10
Multivitamin Covering your bases $8‚Äì15
  üí° Total = ~$50 or less if you catch a sale üõí Pair this with food-first healing, and you‚Äôre golden. üß° Real Talk: If You Can‚Äôt Afford Supplements Right Now‚Ä¶ You‚Äôre not behind. You‚Äôre not failing. You‚Äôre still healing ‚Äî because food, movement, and nervous system regulation are free tools that WORK. Focus on what you can do:
  • Get outside.
  • Eat protein every meal.
  • Walk after you eat.
  • Sleep 7+ hours.
  • Support your gut with whole foods and herbs.
Supplements help, but you are the real medicine.

item.title: ü•¥ The Myth: ‚ÄúEating Healthy Is Too Expensive‚Äù
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
How many times have you thought: ‚ÄúI‚Äôd eat healthier, but I can‚Äôt afford all that organic, gluten-free, dairy-free, keto whatever stuff.‚Äù And yeah, if you‚Äôre shopping with a $16 smoothie recipe and a celebrity wellness influencer‚Äôs pantry in mind, it will get pricey. But healing PCOS isn‚Äôt about labels. It‚Äôs about strategy ‚Äî and blood sugar balance. Let‚Äôs break this down: Balancing your hormones = balancing your blood sugar + reducing inflammation + supporting digestion. And you can do all of that with simple, low-cost, real food.   üí° Budget Rule #1: Focus on Real Food Staples You don‚Äôt need fancy ingredients. Start with whole foods you can repurpose across multiple meals. üõí Hormone-Supportive Budget Staples:
Proteins Healthy Fats Smart Carbs/Fiber Flavor & Extras
Eggs Olive oil Sweet potatoes Garlic, onion
Canned tuna/salmon Avocados Lentils, chickpeas Ginger, lemon
Ground turkey Sunflower seed butter Brown rice, quinoa Spices: turmeric, cumin
Canned beans Flax/chia seeds Oats, cassava, GF tortillas Apple cider vinegar
Chicken thighs Tahini, coconut oil Frozen mixed vegetables Nutritional yeast
‚ú® These stretch across breakfasts, bowls, soups, stir-fries, and snacks ‚Äî all without buying a ton of random stuff. üçΩÔ∏è Budget Rule #2: Build a PCOS Plate for $5 or Less Every meal should aim for 3 key elements:
  • ‚úÖ Protein (eggs, chicken, lentils)
  • ‚úÖ Healthy fat (avocado, olive oil, seeds)
  • ‚úÖ Fiber-rich carb (sweet potatoes, quinoa, veggies)
Example: $4.85 Hormone-Loving Lunch
  • ¬Ω cup cooked quinoa
  • 1 cup saut√©ed kale + frozen peppers
  • 2 scrambled eggs
  • Topped with olive oil + hemp seeds + lemon
Simple. Balanced. Zero blood sugar crash. üç≤ Budget Rule #3: Batch Cook Like a Hormone Boss Cooking a few things once can save you $ and mental energy all week. Here‚Äôs a cheap & easy lineup to prep on Sundays:
  • üç† Roasted sweet potatoes
  • ü•ö Hard-boiled eggs
  • üçõ One big hormone-friendly curry or chili (use lentils, beans, or ground turkey)
  • ü•ó Chopped raw veg for snacking
  • üåæ A grain: brown rice, quinoa, or oats
  • ‚ú® One batch of Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls (because snacks are self-care)
‚û° Use these as mix-and-match building blocks for breakfast bowls, quick lunches, and no-fuss dinners. üíÅ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Smart Budget Tips for Grocery Shopping:
  • üõí Shop the sales FIRST ‚Äî then build your meal plan around what‚Äôs affordable
  • üßä Frozen is your friend ‚Äî frozen berries, greens, cauliflower rice = nutrient-packed & cost-effective
  • üß∫ Bulk bins > pre-packaged ‚Äî buy seeds, spices, and oats this way to save major cash
  • üì¶ Store brands over name brands ‚Äî always
  • üí° Skip ‚Äúhealth halos‚Äù ‚Äî gluten-free cookies and $12 granola aren‚Äôt health foods, they‚Äôre marketing
üçΩÔ∏è 5 Budget-Friendly Hormone-Loving Meals
  1. Chickpea Sweet Potato Stew
  • Canned chickpeas + onion + garlic + sweet potatoes + turmeric
  • Simmer with veggie broth + coconut milk
  1. Egg + Veggie Power Bowl
  • Scrambled eggs + saut√©ed spinach + brown rice + tahini drizzle
  1. Tuna Salad Wraps
  • Canned tuna + avocado + lemon + mustard + chopped celery in lettuce leaves
  1. One-Pot Turkey + Lentil Chili
  • Ground turkey + canned lentils + tomatoes + bell peppers + spices
  1. Overnight Oats (Hormone Edition)
  • Oats + almond milk + flax seeds + cinnamon + frozen berries + scoop of protein powder
üí¨ Real Talk: You Don‚Äôt Need to Be Perfect ‚Äî You Just Need to Be Consistent You‚Äôre not failing because you didn‚Äôt buy organic. You‚Äôre not behind because you‚Äôre making meals with $1.99 beans instead of bison liver and sea moss. You‚Äôre resourceful. You‚Äôre learning. You‚Äôre supporting your hormones with what you‚Äôve got ‚Äî and that‚Äôs powerful AF.

item.title: ‚ú® The Truth: You Don‚Äôt Have to Buy Your Way to Healing
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Some of the most effective tools for PCOS support are things that don‚Äôt cost anything ‚Äî they just require your time, your awareness, and your willingness to slow down. We‚Äôve been taught that healing comes in fancy packaging or with a high price tag. But here‚Äôs what I want you to remember: The things that move the needle the most ‚Äî like blood sugar balance, stress support, and movement ‚Äî are usually free. So let‚Äôs break down the top habits that support hormone healing without draining your bank account. üö∂‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 1. Walking (Seriously. Just Walk.) Forget bootcamp. Forget $180/month gyms. Walking is one of the BEST forms of movement for PCOS. Why it works:
  • Supports insulin sensitivity
  • Lowers cortisol
  • Reduces inflammation
  • Improves digestion and lymphatic flow
  • Helps regulate appetite and mood
üéØ Try:
  • A 10-minute walk after meals = blood sugar GOLD
  • 20‚Äì30 minutes a day of steady, joyful movement (not punishment)
  • Walk while you listen to a podcast, music, or complete silence ‚Äî whatever feeds your nervous system
üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 2. Nervous System Regulation PCOS isn‚Äôt just a hormone thing ‚Äî it‚Äôs a stress thing. When your body is constantly in ‚Äúfight or flight,‚Äù it‚Äôs going to deprioritize things like ovulation, digestion, and hormone balance. So we have to tell your nervous system: you‚Äôre safe now. Free Tools That Help:
  • ‚ú® Box Breathing: Inhale 4, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4
  • ‚ú® Cold Water Splash: On your face for vagus nerve activation
  • ‚ú® Humming/Singing: Yep, activates your vagus nerve
  • ‚ú® Grounding: Stand barefoot outside for 5‚Äì10 minutes
  • ‚ú® Journaling: Release what you‚Äôre holding, daily or as needed
You don‚Äôt need a meditation app. You need a quiet moment to check in with your body. That‚Äôs free. üå± 3. DIY Seed Cycling (Under $5 a Month) Seed cycling is a gentle way to support estrogen and progesterone throughout your cycle using real food. How to Do It:
  • Days 1‚Äì14 (Follicular phase): 1 tbsp flax + 1 tbsp pumpkin seeds daily
  • Days 15‚Äì28 (Luteal phase): 1 tbsp sunflower + 1 tbsp sesame seeds daily
üí° Buy in bulk, grind fresh if possible, store in the fridge. Mix them into:
  • Smoothies
  • Oatmeal
  • Yogurt bowls
  • Chia pudding
  • Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls üòè
üçµ 4. Herbal Teas: A Budget-Friendly Wellness Hack Teas are a super affordable way to bring in hormone support, digestive support, and stress reduction. Tea Faves by Goal:
Goal Tea Recommendation
Cramp relief Raspberry leaf, ginger
Stress + sleep Chamomile, lavender, lemon balm
Bloating + gut Peppermint, fennel, ginger
Estrogen support Dandelion, nettle, green tea
Cravings/Mood Cinnamon, licorice root, cacao husk
‚ú® Most bulk teas cost less than $6 and last weeks. üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 5. Free or Low-Cost Movement If you can‚Äôt afford a gym, that‚Äôs not a problem. YouTube is overflowing with free movement options that are PCOS-friendly. Try:
  • Yoga with Adriene (YouTube)
  • Melissa Wood Health ($10/month if you want a low-cost gentle option)
  • Dance parties in your kitchen
  • 10-minute stretch flows
  • Bodyweight circuits at home
Remember: you‚Äôre moving to feel better, not burn calories. üì≤ 6. Track Your Cycle for Free Understanding your cycle is essential with PCOS ‚Äî especially because it can be irregular. And while fancy hormone trackers exist, you can start with free apps or a printable calendar. Free Tools:
  • Clue or Flo app (free versions)
  • Paper tracker (bonus: mindful connection)
  • Free basal body temp tracking sheets
  • Cervical mucus notes in your journal or app
üîç Track for at least 2‚Äì3 months to start seeing your patterns. üíñ Final Word: This Chapter Isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúExtra‚Äù ‚Äî It‚Äôs the Foundation If you‚Äôre doing none of these things and only taking supplements? You‚Äôll probably feel frustrated. If you‚Äôre doing just these things without any supplements? You‚Äôll still make progress. These tools are about creating a healing environment ‚Äî a body that feels safe, supported, and ready to rebalance. And the price tag? $0‚Äì$5. Can‚Äôt beat that.

item.title: üí° The Vibe: Strategy > Stress
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
If the idea of grocery shopping for your hormones makes your eyes glaze over, trust me ‚Äî I get it. Between reading labels, decoding what‚Äôs ‚Äúhealthy,‚Äù and trying not to spend your rent money in one aisle, it can feel overwhelming. So let‚Äôs simplify this. Shopping for PCOS doesn‚Äôt mean a cart full of kale and kombucha. It means stocking up on real food that works for your body ‚Äî and stretching that food across the week like the resourceful goddess you are. üß† Step 1: Know the Healing Goals We‚Äôre not just shopping for random ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù stuff. We‚Äôre shopping for foods that support:
  • ‚úÖ Blood sugar balance
  • ‚úÖ Gut health
  • ‚úÖ Inflammation reduction
  • ‚úÖ Hormone production + detox
  • ‚úÖ Ovulation support
‚Ä¶and we‚Äôre doing it without $18 ‚Äúsuperfoods‚Äù or protein powders that taste like wet cardboard. üîé Step 2: Shop by Category (Not by Trend) Here‚Äôs your core PCOS-friendly grocery list ‚Äî simple, affordable, and easy to customize based on sales and your taste buds. ü•¨ Produce (fresh or frozen ‚Äî frozen is often cheaper and just as nutrient-rich)
  • Spinach, kale, arugula
  • Broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage
  • Carrots, sweet potatoes, beets
  • Zucchini, bell peppers, onions
  • Lemons, limes, garlic, ginger
  • Berries (frozen = budget-friendly magic)
  • Bananas (green or slightly underripe for gut health)
üçó Proteins
  • Pasture-raised eggs (or whatever you can afford)
  • Ground turkey or chicken thighs
  • Canned wild salmon, sardines, or tuna
  • Canned beans (chickpeas, black beans, lentils)
  • Greek yogurt (plain, full-fat)
  • Protein powder (optional ‚Äî go budget if you use it)
ü•ë Healthy Fats
  • Olive oil or avocado oil
  • Nut butters (almond, sunflower seed, peanut)
  • Coconut oil
  • Chia, flax, pumpkin, and sunflower seeds
  • Avocados (yes, get the bagged ones)
üåæ Smart Carbs + Fiber
  • Brown rice or quinoa
  • Gluten-free oats
  • Lentils and black beans
  • Cassava or almond flour (optional baking staples)
  • Sweet potatoes, squash, carrots
üßÇ Extras That Matter
  • Apple cider vinegar
  • Nutritional yeast (B vitamin love)
  • Herbal teas (peppermint, ginger, raspberry leaf)
  • Coconut aminos (soy sauce alternative)
  • Spices: turmeric, cinnamon, cumin, garlic powder
üí∞ Step 3: Budget Boss Tips (So You Don‚Äôt Overspend)
  1. Shop the sales, not the trends.
    • Base your meals around what‚Äôs affordable that week ‚Äî not what your feed says is ‚Äúin.‚Äù
  2. Choose frozen or canned over fresh when needed.
    • Frozen spinach, berries, cauliflower rice = budget GOLD.
  3. Skip the ‚Äúhealth halo‚Äù snacks.
    • $7 kale chips or gluten-free cookies are still processed food. You can DIY snacks for half the price.
  4. Pick 2‚Äì3 core meals to rotate.
    • This cuts down on food waste, decision fatigue, and cost.
  5. Buy in bulk ‚Äî but only for things you actually use.
    • Seeds, oats, lentils, and spices? Yes.
    • Random almond flour crackers? Probably not.
ü•£ Step 4: Create a ‚ÄúRemixable‚Äù Grocery Plan Here‚Äôs how to stretch your grocery haul into a full week: Meal Base #1: Sweet potatoes + turkey + greens
  • Remix as: bowls, hashes, taco filling, or salad topper
Meal Base #2: Quinoa + canned beans + veggies
  • Remix as: stir-fry, burrito bowl, warm salad, soup base
Meal Base #3: Eggs + greens + whatever‚Äôs leftover
  • Remix as: frittatas, breakfast burritos, scrambles
Snack Base:
  • Apple + nut butter
  • Yogurt + flax + berries
  • Seed & Slay balls
  • Veggies + hummus
  • Chia pudding
‚ú® You don‚Äôt need 21 different meals for 7 days. You need a few solid combos you actually like. üëÄ Pro Tip: Read Labels Without Getting a Headache Keep it simple:
  • Look for ingredients you can pronounce
  • Skip products with added sugars, ‚Äúvegetable oils,‚Äù or mystery flavorings
  • Aim for 5 ingredients or fewer in packaged foods
If the ingredient list looks like a science experiment, put it back, bestie. üéØ Final Word: This Is About Progress, Not Perfection Some weeks you‚Äôll get the organic pasture-raised everything. Some weeks you‚Äôll be grabbing canned beans and frozen spinach on sale. Both are valid. Both are healing. Both are part of your journey. What matters most is showing up for yourself with the resources you do have ‚Äî not the ones you wish you had.

item.title: üí≠ First Things First: Healing ‚â† Perfection
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
There‚Äôs a version of ‚Äúhealing‚Äù floating around social media that‚Äôs all yoga mats, green smoothies, and $100 lymphatic brushes. Here‚Äôs the real version:
  • Sometimes healing is eating the eggs you can afford, not organic pastured ones.
  • Sometimes it‚Äôs skipping the workout because you chose sleep.
  • Sometimes it‚Äôs crying on the kitchen floor because your period showed up again ‚Äî but getting up anyway.
Healing isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs persistent. And you are doing better than you think. üß† What Healing Actually Looks Like Over Time Let‚Äôs get real about what to expect ‚Äî not just physically, but emotionally.
Early Stages (0‚Äì3 months) Mid Stages (3‚Äì6 months) Long-Term (6‚Äì12+ months)
Learning your body‚Äôs patterns More regular cycles Improved ovulation/fertility
Building a grocery/meal rhythm Clearer skin, less bloating Weight regulation (if needed)
Tired, but hopeful Energy steadier, fewer crashes Fewer symptoms, more confidence
Overwhelmed at times Wins + setbacks (normal!) Feeling in flow with your body
Healing is not linear. There will be flare-ups, fatigue, frustration. But there will also be breakthroughs. Lightness. And moments where you realize: ‚ÄúOh. I feel like me again.‚Äù üõ†Ô∏è Tracking Progress (Without Obsessing) You don‚Äôt need to weigh yourself every week or track macros like a spreadsheet. You do need ways to measure how your body is responding. Try tracking:
  • ü©∏ Period frequency, flow, and symptoms
  • üå°Ô∏è Ovulation signs (mucus, LH strips, BBT)
  • üåø Energy, mood, and sleep
  • üåª Cravings and digestion
  • üí™ What‚Äôs getting easier (stairs? sleep? saying no?)
You can use a cycle tracking app or just jot it down in a notebook. Make it simple. Make it honest. üß° Body Love While You Heal This one‚Äôs important: You are allowed to love your body while still working on it. PCOS can mess with your confidence. Hair where you don‚Äôt want it, periods that ghost you, weight that won‚Äôt budge ‚Äî it‚Äôs a lot. But your body is not your enemy. It‚Äôs not failing you. It‚Äôs speaking to you. What you may see as symptoms are actually signs ‚Äî and you‚Äôre learning how to read them. That‚Äôs powerful. Start with:
  • Wearing clothes that make you feel good now
  • Nourishing your body with kindness, not punishment
  • Saying ‚Äúthank you‚Äù for what your body can do today
You‚Äôre healing a relationship ‚Äî not just with your hormones, but with yourself. üí¨ Building a Support Squad (On the Cheap) You don‚Äôt need a full wellness team. But you do need support. Free or low-cost ways to get it:
  • ‚úÖ Join online PCOS communities or subreddits
  • ‚úÖ Follow educators who teach, not just sell
  • ‚úÖ Ask your doctor for sliding scale labs or referrals
  • ‚úÖ Use community health centers for check-ins
  • ‚úÖ Create a healing buddy system ‚Äî cook or check in weekly with a friend
You‚Äôre not meant to heal alone. üåû Final Words: You‚Äôre Not Just Healing ‚Äî You‚Äôre Reclaiming This guide wasn‚Äôt about quick fixes. It was about reclaiming power in a world that‚Äôs made PCOS feel like a mystery wrapped in shame and marked ‚Äúexpensive.‚Äù You‚Äôve learned how to:
  • Eat for your hormones without going broke
  • Supplement strategically
  • Use free tools that support your whole body
  • Grocery shop like a PCOS girl boss
  • Track your progress and celebrate every win
You‚Äôve got this. Even on hard days. Especially on hard days. Healing isn‚Äôt about doing it all. It‚Äôs about doing what you can with what you have ‚Äî and believing that it‚Äôs enough. And sis‚Ä¶ it is. You are. You made it through ‚Äî and I‚Äôm proud of you. Whether you‚Äôre batch-cooking sweet potatoes, walking after meals, or just remembering to breathe ‚Äî that‚Äôs healing. It‚Äôs not about being perfect. It‚Äôs about showing up for yourself, again and again. If you want more support, I‚Äôm here for that too. üíõ Let‚Äôs take your healing deeper together ‚Äî with personalized nutrition, hormone support, and real-life strategies that work with your body. üåø Visit HouseofJay.net to book a 1:1 session or check out my signature course, Rooted in Balance. You are not behind. You are right on time. And sis ‚Äî you‚Äôre doing better than you think. üíõ

item.title: 7 Day Cheap & Chic PCOS Meal Plan
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Simple, satisfying meals to nourish your hormones without wrecking your wallet. "No gluten, no dairy, no overpriced snacks ‚Äî just real food, smart combos, and budget boss vibes." üåû DAY 1 Breakfast: Scrambled eggs with saut√©ed spinach + sweet potato hash Snack: Apple slices with sunflower seed butter Lunch: Chickpea + veggie stir-fry over brown rice Snack: Chia pudding (made with almond milk + flax) Dinner: Turkey & black bean chili (make enough for leftovers!) üí° Prep tip: Cook a big batch of rice and chili for Days 2‚Äì3. üåû DAY 2 Breakfast: Overnight oats with frozen berries, flaxseed & cinnamon Snack: Hard-boiled egg + cucumber slices Lunch: Leftover turkey chili + quinoa or brown rice Snack: Carrot sticks + hummus Dinner: Garlic roasted sweet potatoes + steamed broccoli + a fried egg üí° Hack: Roast extra sweet potatoes + broccoli for future dinners. üåû DAY 3 Breakfast: Chia pudding topped with banana + cinnamon Snack: Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls (or DIY version!) Lunch: Tuna salad lettuce wraps + leftover sweet potatoes Snack: Unsweetened yogurt + flax + cinnamon Dinner: Lentil curry with canned lentils, tomato, garlic, and frozen veggies üí° $ saver: Canned lentils + frozen veg = $2 meal win. üåû DAY 4 Breakfast: Protein smoothie (banana, flax, oats, cinnamon, protein powder or egg whites) Snack: Celery + sunflower seed butter Lunch: Quinoa + roasted veggies + tahini drizzle Snack: Popcorn with olive oil + sea salt Dinner: Scrambled eggs + saut√©ed kale + avocado (breakfast for dinner) üí° Budget bonus: Eggs = one of the cheapest high-quality proteins. üåû DAY 5 Breakfast: Overnight oats with chia, almond butter + cinnamon Snack: Hard-boiled egg + carrot sticks Lunch: Lentil salad with cucumbers, olive oil + lemon (use leftovers!) Snack: Apple + tahini Dinner: Chickpea sweet potato stew with garlic, onion, and turmeric üí° Cook once, eat twice: Stew can stretch to lunch on Day 6. üåû DAY 6 Breakfast: Fried eggs + roasted sweet potatoes + greens Snack: Yogurt with cinnamon + chia Lunch: Leftover chickpea stew or a simple veggie wrap Snack: Banana + almond butter Dinner: Zucchini stir fry with rice + scrambled egg + tamari üí° Budget spice swap: Use coconut aminos or low-sodium soy sauce. üåû DAY 7 Breakfast: Smoothie bowl (frozen berries, banana, chia, water) + seed topping Snack: Rice cake + sunflower seed butter Lunch: Sweet potato & lentil mash + greens Snack: Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls Dinner: Sheet pan dinner: roasted carrots, broccoli, onion + baked egg or canned salmon üí° Closeout tip: Use up all leftover veg in the sheet pan meal! üõçÔ∏è Budget Grocery Staples Used:

Jay's Seed & Slay Balls‚Ñ¢ - Craving Control Kit Snack your way through your cycle with Jay's Seed & Slay Balls‚Ñ¢. These phase-based hormone bites are crafted to satisfy cravings while nourishing your body with the ingredients it actually needs. Each recipe supports your hormones, blood sugar, mood, and cravings ‚Äî naturally.

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ‚ú® Follicular Phase: Glowballs

  • Ingredients: - 1/2 cup ground flaxseed - 1/2 cup ground pumpkin seeds - 1/4 cup almond butter - 1 tbsp coconut oil - 1 tsp maca powder - 1/4 tsp cinnamon - Zest of 1 lemon - Optional: 1 tbsp freeze-dried raspberries or bee pollen - Optional: 1‚Äì2 tsp maple syrup or date syrup

¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† üåô Luteal Phase: Calm & Collected Balls

item.title: üí¨ Welcome Friend
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
If you‚Äôre here, chances are something feels off ‚Äî your body, your energy, your mood, maybe even your confidence. And whether or not anyone‚Äôs said it out loud yet‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre wondering if testosterone has something to do with it. First, let‚Äôs clear something up: testosterone isn‚Äôt just about sex or muscles. It‚Äôs central to your health. In fact, it‚Äôs one of the most important hormones you‚Äôve got. This lesson is all about helping you understand what testosterone really is, what it actually does in the male body, and how to recognize when it‚Äôs not doing its job. üî¨ What Is Testosterone? Testosterone is a steroid hormone primarily produced in the testes (about 95%) and in smaller amounts by the adrenal glands. It‚Äôs regulated by a hormonal feedback loop called the HPG axis ‚Äî which stands for Hypothalamus ‚Üí Pituitary ‚Üí Gonads. üìà Here‚Äôs how it works:
  1. The hypothalamus in your brain releases GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone)
  2. That signals the pituitary gland to release LH (luteinizing hormone)
  3. LH travels to the testes, telling them to produce testosterone
Testosterone levels are tightly monitored by your brain ‚Äî and any disruptions along this axis (stress, inflammation, head trauma, nutrient deficiencies, etc.) can lower production. üìö Source: Endotext.org ‚Äì Male Hypogonadism Physiology üß† So, What Does Testosterone Actually Do? Testosterone isn‚Äôt just about building biceps or fueling sex drive. It acts on almost every system in the body ‚Äî from your muscles to your brain to your bones to your metabolism. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of its major roles:
System Testosterone‚Äôs Role
üîã Energy & Vitality Boosts mitochondrial function (your cell‚Äôs energy engines)
üß† Mood & Brain Supports dopamine, confidence, memory, and focus
üí™ Muscle Increases protein synthesis and muscle mass
üî• Fat Metabolism Helps reduce visceral fat and prevent insulin resistance
üõè Libido & Sexual Function Stimulates desire and supports erectile function
ü¶¥ Bone Health Maintains bone density and reduces fracture risk
ü©∏ Blood Production Stimulates red blood cell production in the bone marrow
üõ† Recovery & Repair Speeds healing, recovery, and tissue maintenance
It even helps regulate immune function, pain tolerance, and stress resilience. üß† Testosterone = Performance + Protection Not just in the gym. In your cells. In your brain. In your whole life. ‚ö†Ô∏è Signs You Might Have Low T Low testosterone can feel like someone turned the volume down on your life ‚Äî you‚Äôre still showing up, but you‚Äôre dragging, distracted, and disconnected.
Symptom What It Might Feel Like
Exhaustion You‚Äôre drained by 2pm, even with sleep
Mood Swings You‚Äôre short-tempered, anxious, or down
Belly Fat Gaining weight around your middle
Brain Fog Struggling to focus, remember, or care
Low Libido Less desire or difficulty with performance
Muscle Loss You feel weaker, less defined, slow to recover
Sleep Problems Trouble falling/staying asleep
Motivation Drop Less drive, purpose, or ‚Äúspark‚Äù
üìâ What‚Äôs Normal vs. What‚Äôs Optimal? The ‚Äúnormal‚Äù testosterone range is often listed as 300‚Äì1,000 ng/dL, but that‚Äôs a huge range ‚Äî and many men feel symptoms well above that 300 cut-off. ‚ö†Ô∏è Lab normal ‚â† functional optimal. You might be told ‚Äúyour labs look fine,‚Äù but if you‚Äôre walking around feeling like a shell of yourself, your numbers don‚Äôt tell the full story. üß© Root Causes of Low T ‚Äî Functional View So why does testosterone drop before you hit 60? From a functional medicine lens, we look at upstream factors ‚Äî what‚Äôs interfering with your body‚Äôs ability to produce, convert, or use testosterone efficiently? üß† The 7 Root Causes to Know:
  1. Chronic Stress
    • Elevates cortisol ‚Üí suppresses LH (the signal to produce T)
    • üìö Source
  2. Sleep Deprivation
    • T is released during deep sleep (especially 3‚Äì6AM). Less sleep = less T.
    • üìö Source: JAMA, 2011
  3. Insulin Resistance & Blood Sugar Swings
    • Belly fat increases aromatase, an enzyme that turns testosterone into estrogen.
    • üìö Source
  4. Gut Dysbiosis & Poor Digestion
    • Low zinc/magnesium absorption = weak hormone production
    • Imbalances can impair hormone detox pathways
    • üìö Source
  5. Inflammation
    • Systemic inflammation suppresses Leydig cell function in the testes
    • üìö Source
  6. Toxin Exposure
    • BPA, phthalates, and pesticides disrupt hormone signaling at the receptor level
    • üìö Source
  7. Low Healthy Fat & Cholesterol Intake
    • Testosterone is made from cholesterol. You need fats to build hormones.
    • üìö Source
‚úÖ Key Takeaways
  • Testosterone isn‚Äôt just a ‚Äúsex hormone‚Äù ‚Äî it affects your brain, body, and resilience
  • Low T can show up in subtle, creeping ways ‚Äî and it‚Äôs more common than most realize
Functional medicine focuses on why your levels are low ‚Äî and that‚Äôs where the solution lives üì£ Next Up: Lesson 2 ‚Äî Fix the Foundations Before we even talk supplements or workouts, we‚Äôre going to lay the foundation: sleep, blood sugar, and stress. Because until those are handled, nothing else will stick. You ready to build your base?

item.title: üß± Foundation 1: Sleep ‚Äî The Nighttime Hormone Factory
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
üí¨ I know ‚Äî when guys think about testosterone, they usually think about workouts and supplements first. But here‚Äôs the truth: if your foundations are off, no amount of protein powder or ashwagandha is going to fix it. This lesson is about the three critical systems that control testosterone behind the scenes ‚Äî and how to reset them naturally so your body can actually build and use testosterone again. üõå Why Sleep Is Step #1 Testosterone follows a circadian rhythm, meaning it rises and falls based on your sleep-wake cycle. The majority of testosterone production happens during deep, slow-wave sleep ‚Äî especially in the early morning hours (between 3‚Äì6AM). Lack of quality sleep = Less testosterone. Period. üìâ One study found that just one week of 5-hour nights caused a 10‚Äì15% drop in testosterone levels. üìö Source: JAMA, 2011 üß† How Poor Sleep Affects T:
  • ‚Üì LH signaling = your testes don‚Äôt get the memo to produce testosterone
  • ‚Üë Cortisol = more stress, more hormone suppression
  • ‚Üì Growth hormone = less repair and recovery
  • ‚Üë Insulin resistance = more belly fat, less usable T
‚úÖ What to Do About It:
  • Get 7.5‚Äì9 hours a night (yes, you need it)
  • Be asleep by 11 PM to catch the deep sleep wave
  • Limit screens 1 hour before bed (blue light blocks melatonin)
  • Use magnesium glycinate or GABA if needed to unwind
  • Make your room cold, dark, and quiet (testosterone loves deep sleep environments)
üß± Foundation 2: Blood Sugar ‚Äî The Silent Testosterone Killer üç© How Blood Sugar Messes with T When you eat lots of refined carbs, sugar, or processed foods, your blood sugar spikes. Your body responds by pumping out insulin. Over time, this leads to:
  • Insulin resistance
  • Weight gain around the belly
  • Increased aromatase activity (An enzyme that literally converts testosterone into estrogen)
üìö Source: Diabetes Care, 2007 ‚ÄúHigh blood sugar doesn‚Äôt just kill energy ‚Äî it converts your testosterone into something it was never meant to be.‚Äù üß† Functional Signs of Blood Sugar Trouble:
  • Energy crashes after meals
  • Cravings for sugar or caffeine mid-day
  • Irritability or ‚Äúhanger‚Äù if meals are skipped
  • Belly fat that‚Äôs hard to lose
‚úÖ How to Fix It:
  • Start meals with protein & fiber (slows down glucose spikes and keeps you full)
  • Ditch sugar + refined carbs (start with soda, candy, white bread, pastries)
  • Use the ‚ÄúMan Plate‚Äù method:
    • 1 fist of protein
    • 1 fist of fiber-rich carbs
    • 1‚Äì2 thumbs of healthy fat
    • Non-starchy veggies as a base
  • Walk after meals ‚Äî even 10 minutes improves glucose control üìö Source: Sports Medicine, 2008
üß± Foundation 3: Stress ‚Äî Cortisol vs. Testosterone üò§ What Stress Does to Hormones When you're under constant pressure (mental, emotional, physical), your brain prioritizes survival. That means cortisol production goes up ‚Äî and testosterone takes a back seat. High cortisol directly reduces:
  • GnRH ‚Üí less LH ‚Üí less testosterone
  • Sleep quality ‚Üí less recovery and production
  • Dopamine & serotonin ‚Üí lower drive, mood, and motivation
üìö Source: Psychoneuroendocrinology, 2005 ‚ÄúYour body can't make testosterone when it thinks you're being chased by a tiger ‚Äî even if the tiger is just your inbox.‚Äù üß† Everyday Stress Triggers That Crash T:
  • Overtraining (yes, workouts can backfire)
  • Under-eating or skipping meals
  • Poor sleep
  • Constant mental stress (work, bills, kids, deadlines)
‚úÖ Tools to Lower Cortisol Naturally:
  • Deep breathing or box breathing (4-4-4-4 pattern)
  • Cold showers or contrast therapy (builds stress resilience)
  • Get outside ‚Äî 20 minutes of sunlight daily
  • Adaptogens: ashwagandha, rhodiola, holy basil (all shown to support cortisol balance)
  • Daily movement that doesn‚Äôt wreck your nervous system ‚Äî like walking, rucking, or mobility work
üì• Self-Check Worksheet :
  • How many hours of sleep am I really getting?
  • Do I wake up refreshed or still tired?
  • Do I feel moody, anxious, or burned out?
  • Am I having cravings, crashes, or constant hunger?
  • Am I training too hard without recovering?
‚úÖ Key Takeaways:
  • Sleep, blood sugar, and stress are the pillars of testosterone production.
  • You cannot out-supplement a broken foundation.
  • Fixing these three systems primes your body to produce, use, and feel your testosterone again.
üîú Up Next: Lesson 3 ‚Äî Fuel for Testosterone Now that we‚Äôve got your base solid, it‚Äôs time to dig into food. The right nutrients can boost testosterone, lower inflammation, and rebuild your metabolism ‚Äî and no, it‚Äôs not all steak and eggs. Let‚Äôs fuel your comeback.

item.title: ‚öôÔ∏è How Hormones Are Made (Quick & Dirty Science)
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
üí¨ You can‚Äôt build a house without bricks. And your body can‚Äôt build hormones without the right raw materials. Testosterone is made from nutrients ‚Äî real ones ‚Äî like protein, healthy fats, minerals, and cholesterol. If you‚Äôre living off toast, protein bars, and coffee, your body‚Äôs running on fumes. This lesson is all about giving your body what it needs to fuel testosterone production, support your metabolism, and rebuild that fire from the inside out.  
  • Hormones like testosterone are made from cholesterol, and assembled using micronutrients like zinc, magnesium, vitamin D, B vitamins, and boron.
  • If your body is missing those materials, or busy dealing with inflammation or blood sugar swings, it downregulates hormone production.
  • üëâ This is how restrictive diets, low-fat trends, or constant ‚Äúclean eating‚Äù can actually work against your hormones.
üç≥ The Top Nutrients for Testosterone (and Where to Get Them)
Nutrient Why You Need It Food Sources
Zinc Essential for LH signaling (which tells the testes to make T); supports immune health & sperm production Red meat, shellfish (especially oysters), pumpkin seeds, chickpeas
Magnesium Boosts free testosterone by lowering SHBG (binding protein that locks up T) Spinach, almonds, dark chocolate, avocados
Vitamin D Acts like a hormone; regulates testosterone & mood Fatty fish, eggs, sunlight, D3 supplements
B Vitamins (esp. B6, B12, Folate) Involved in methylation, energy metabolism, and hormone detox Eggs, beef liver, salmon, leafy greens
Boron Supports free T levels, reduces estrogen Raisins, avocados, prunes, almonds
Omega-3s Anti-inflammatory, helps regulate hormones and cellular health Salmon, sardines, flax seeds, walnuts
Cholesterol Precursor for hormone synthesis Egg yolks, grass-fed butter, full-fat dairy, pasture-raised meats
üìö Sources:
  • Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 2018
  • Hormone and Metabolic Research, 2011
  • Biological Trace Element Research, 2010
üçΩÔ∏è The ‚ÄúMan Plate‚Äù Formula for Hormone Health Let‚Äôs keep it simple but powerful. This eating pattern works with your hormones, not against them: ‚û§ Build Your Plate Like This:
  • ü•© 1 fist-sized serving of protein (Beef, chicken, eggs, fish, tofu, or a clean protein shake)
  • ü•¶ 1‚Äì2 fists of colorful veggies (Fiber helps balance blood sugar + detox estrogen)
  • ü•î 1 fist of slow carbs (Sweet potatoes, rice, beans, oats ‚Äî avoid blood sugar spikes)
  • ü•ë 1‚Äì2 thumbs of healthy fats (Avocado, olive oil, nuts, seeds, egg yolks, grass-fed butter)
üß† Rule of thumb: Every meal should include protein, fiber, and fat. That‚Äôs how you keep blood sugar stable, cortisol low, and testosterone production humming. üö´ Foods That Tank Testosterone Let‚Äôs talk about what to cut down ‚Äî not because we‚Äôre being restrictive, but because these foods are proven to interfere with hormone health:
üö´ Food Why It‚Äôs a Problem
Refined Sugar Increases insulin resistance and belly fat, converts T to estrogen
Excess Alcohol Damages liver (which clears estrogen) and suppresses T production
Soy Protein Isolate In large amounts, may increase estrogenic compounds
Seed Oils (canola, corn, soybean) High in omega-6s = pro-inflammatory = bad news for hormone balance
Ultra-Processed Foods Nutrient poor, gut damaging, loaded with hormone-disrupting additives
üìö Sources:
  • Clinical Endocrinology, 2016
  • Nutrition Journal, 2010
ü•§ Testosterone-Boosting Meal Ideas üî• Breakfast
  • 3 pasture-raised eggs scrambled in olive oil
  • ¬Ω avocado
  • Sweet potato hash with spinach
  • Black coffee or green tea
üèãÔ∏è Post-Workout
  • Grass-fed beef or bison burger
  • Roasted veggies & wild rice
  • Pumpkin seeds on top
üß† On-the-Go Smoothie
  • 1 scoop grass-fed protein
  • 1 tbsp almond butter
  • 1 cup frozen berries
  • ¬Ω avocado
  • Unsweetened almond milk
  • Add-ins: flax seed, maca, cinnamon, greens
‚úÖ Key Takeaways:
  • Testosterone is made from nutrients, not magic. Eat like your hormones depend on it ‚Äî because they do.
  • Focus on protein, fats, and colorful, fiber-rich carbs ‚Äî that‚Äôs your testosterone trifecta.
  • Ditch the sugar, ultra-processed junk, and inflammatory oils.
  • When in doubt, go whole food, high color, high quality.
üîú Up Next: Lesson 4 ‚Äì Boost It Naturally Now that your foundation is solid and your meals are on point, let‚Äôs talk strategy ‚Äî how to actually boost your testosterone levels through training, movement, and smart supplementation. This is where the fun begins.

item.title: üèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Part 1: Train Like Testosterone Depends on It ‚Äî Because It Does
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
üí¨ Alright ‚Äî now that your foundation‚Äôs strong and your plate is dialed in, it‚Äôs time to get strategic. In this lesson, we‚Äôre focusing on how to naturally increase testosterone production using functional tools that work with your body ‚Äî not against it. Think of this as the tune-up phase ‚Äî where we bring the systems back online, fire up testosterone production, and start feeling like the powerful, energized version of you again. üí£ Best Training for Boosting T Not all workouts boost testosterone. In fact, too much training (especially cardio) can increase cortisol and lower your T. ‚úÖ What Works:
  1. Heavy Lifting / Resistance Training
    • Compound lifts (squats, deadlifts, bench, pull-ups)
    • Low rep ranges (5‚Äì8 reps, 3‚Äì5 sets)
    • 3‚Äì4x/week max, with recovery built in üìö Source: European Journal of Applied Physiology, 2010
  2. High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT)
    • Short bursts of all-out effort (sprints, sled pushes, air bike)
    • 20‚Äì30 min max, 2x/week üìö Source: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research, 2012
  3. Walking & Zone 2 Cardio
    • Low-stress movement helps regulate cortisol & support fat burning
    • 8‚Äì10k steps/day or 30 mins steady movement
‚ùå What to Avoid: üö´ Overtraining | Leads to elevated cortisol and decreased T | üö´ Chronic cardio | Suppresses testosterone & can burn muscle | üö´ Training without recovery | Blocks testosterone production and increases inflammation |   üßò‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Part 2: Lifestyle Habits That Raise T Naturally
Habit Why It Works
Morning Sunlight Regulates circadian rhythm ‚Üí better sleep ‚Üí more T
Cold Exposure (Cold Showers / Ice Baths) Stimulates dopamine and testosterone; lowers inflammation
Breathwork / Meditation Lowers cortisol; improves oxygenation and recovery
Deep Sleep (7.5‚Äì9 hrs) Testosterone is released during deep sleep
Grounding / Nature Time Balances nervous system ‚Üí lowers stress load
Sexual Activity Increases testosterone & dopamine; strengthens HPG axis response
These aren't just ‚Äúwellness trends‚Äù ‚Äî they are biological recovery tools that keep your body in a testosterone-producing state.   üíä Part 3: Supplements That Actually Work Here are the top evidence-based supplements shown to support testosterone production when paired with foundation work (sleep, blood sugar, training).
Supplement What It Does Dose Notes
Vitamin D3 Boosts testosterone in deficient men 3,000‚Äì5,000 IU/day Get labs checked
Zinc Essential for T production and sperm health 15‚Äì30 mg/day Don‚Äôt overdo ‚Äî too much can suppress copper
Magnesium (Glycinate or Threonate) Supports free T and muscle recovery 200‚Äì400 mg/day Best at night
Boron Increases free T and lowers SHBG 3‚Äì6 mg/day In raisins, prunes, or supplements
Ashwagandha Adaptogen that lowers cortisol and raises T 300‚Äì600 mg/day KSM-66 is most studied
Tongkat Ali (Eurycoma longifolia) Boosts libido, energy, and T in some men 200‚Äì400 mg/day Especially in men with low baseline levels
Maca Root Supports libido and mood 1.5‚Äì3g/day Great in smoothies or capsules
üìö Sources:
  • Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition, 2018
  • Andrologia, 2010 ‚Äì Tongkat Ali
  • Evidence-Based Complementary and Alternative Medicine, 2015 ‚Äì Ashwagandha
  üö® Supplement Smarts
  • Supplements are tools, not magic. If you don‚Äôt fix the foundation, you‚Äôre wasting your money.
  • Always check for clean sourcing (no fillers, artificial dyes, or hidden estrogenic compounds).
  • Stack strategically ‚Äî start with the basics (vitamin D, zinc, magnesium) before trying the big hitters.
‚úÖ Key Takeaways:
  • Lift heavy, rest hard. Testosterone is made during recovery, not during burnout.
  • Use your body daily ‚Äî walking, lifting, breathing ‚Äî movement is medicine.
  • Use supplements wisely ‚Äî they help only when the foundation is in place.
  • Consistency wins. Don‚Äôt sprint. Build.
üîú Up Next: Lesson 5 ‚Äì Let‚Äôs Talk About It We‚Äôre closing out this series by talking about the real stuff ‚Äî libido, confidence, mental health, and when (or if) testosterone therapy makes sense. Because this isn‚Äôt just about levels. It‚Äôs about life.

item.title: ‚ù§Ô∏è Part 1: Low T Isn‚Äôt Just Physical ‚Äî It‚Äôs Emotional
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
üí¨ You‚Äôve made it this far ‚Äî and that means you care enough to take action. That already sets you apart. But here‚Äôs the deal: this last lesson is the one most guys skip. Because it‚Äôs not just about training, supplements, or labs ‚Äî it‚Äôs about you. Your mental health. Your sex drive. Your confidence. Your relationships. And what to do when you feel like something‚Äôs still missing. Let‚Äôs get into it. Low testosterone doesn‚Äôt just mess with your muscles. It can shift your entire internal world. Emotional and Mental Signs of Low T:
  • Feeling emotionally flat or unmotivated
  • Losing interest in things you used to enjoy
  • Irritability or unpredictable mood swings
  • Social withdrawal
  • Feeling ‚Äúnumb‚Äù ‚Äî not sad, but disconnected
üìö Source: Psychoneuroendocrinology, 2008 Testosterone influences dopamine and serotonin ‚Äî the neurotransmitters that control motivation, reward, and mood. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not just tired. You‚Äôre not just moody. Your chemistry might be out of sync ‚Äî and that‚Äôs fixable.‚Äù   üî• Part 2: Libido, Confidence & Performance One of the most common signs of low T is a noticeable dip in sex drive or performance ‚Äî but most men don‚Äôt talk about it. Low testosterone can lead to:
  • Reduced interest in sex
  • Difficulty maintaining erections
  • Less sensitivity or pleasure during sex
  • Feelings of shame, anxiety, or frustration
But it‚Äôs not just about sex ‚Äî it‚Äôs about confidence. That feeling of being grounded, capable, assertive. When testosterone dips, so can that inner fire. It‚Äôs not just about performing in the bedroom. It‚Äôs about showing up in your life with energy, purpose, and power. üß† Part 3: When Should You Consider TRT (Testosterone Replacement Therapy)? Let‚Äôs be clear: this course is about natural restoration first. But in some cases, TRT can be life-changing ‚Äî especially if:
  • You‚Äôve optimized sleep, stress, nutrition, and training
  • Your labs show consistent low total and free testosterone
  • You‚Äôre still symptomatic (low libido, energy, motivation)
  • You‚Äôve ruled out deeper root causes (thyroid, pituitary, trauma)
TRT is a tool. It‚Äôs not a shortcut, but it‚Äôs also not something to fear. When used correctly and monitored, it can be part of a functional plan to restore vitality. üìö Source: Endocrine Society Clinical Guidelines, 2018 ‚ö†Ô∏è Know This Before You Start:
  • TRT is a lifelong commitment for many men
  • It suppresses natural production of testosterone
  • Must be monitored for blood thickness, estrogen, prostate health
  • Always work with a provider who tests total and free T, SHBG, estradiol, DHT, CBC, lipids, and PSA
  üßë‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è How to Talk to Your Doctor or Practitioner
  • Bring your symptom list (use the worksheet from Lesson 1)
  • Ask for total & free testosterone, estradiol, LH, SHBG, prolactin
  • Be honest. Don‚Äôt sugarcoat how you‚Äôre feeling.
  • If you‚Äôre dismissed or told ‚Äúyou‚Äôre fine,‚Äù seek a functional or hormone-literate provider
You don‚Äôt need to be a doctor to advocate for your health ‚Äî you just need to be informed, and relentless in your pursuit of feeling better. ‚úÖ Final Key Takeaways:
  • Testosterone isn‚Äôt just a number ‚Äî it‚Äôs a signal. It reflects the health of your brain, gut, metabolism, and emotional well-being.
  • You can reclaim your energy, confidence, and performance through strategic lifestyle changes, targeted nutrition, and, if needed, clinical support.
  • You deserve to feel like yourself again ‚Äî and this course gave you the roadmap to start that journey.
üèÅ Ready to Take the Next Step? If you‚Äôve made it through this guide ‚Äî first off, I‚Äôm proud of you. Not just for reading, but for showing up. For asking questions. For realizing you deserve to feel better in your body, your mind, and your life. Now you‚Äôve got the tools. You understand your hormones. You‚Äôve got a roadmap. But if you‚Äôre still feeling stuck ‚Äî or you want help personalizing the plan ‚Äî you don‚Äôt have to do this alone. üîß 1:1 Coaching Is Available At House of Jay, I offer personalized hormone support and functional nutrition coaching to help you:
  • Decode your symptoms and lab results
  • Build a sustainable, strength-supportive routine
  • Create a nutrition and lifestyle plan that actually fits your life
  • Get accountability, clarity, and support along the way
This isn‚Äôt a cookie-cutter protocol. It‚Äôs a conversation. It‚Äôs coaching that sees you as a whole person ‚Äî not just your testosterone numbers. üìû Book a free discovery call or reach out directly: üåê HouseofJay.net üìß HouseofJay@writeme.com You deserve to feel strong, grounded, and energized again. Let‚Äôs tune up your hormones ‚Äî and your life ‚Äî together. ‚Äî Jacquelyn Fryndej-Cruz Functional Nutrition & Integrative Wellness Practitioner Founder, House of Jay

item.title: üí¨ Welcome
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded:
Hey, friend ‚Äî If you‚Äôre here, I already know something important about you: you want to show up well for someone you love. You might not know how. You might be scared, overwhelmed, unsure of what to say or do ‚Äî but you care. And that means you‚Äôre already doing more right than you know. This course isn‚Äôt about turning you into a medical expert or giving you a script for every moment. It‚Äôs about helping you show up with presence, not perfection. It‚Äôs about honoring the emotions, the mess, the humanness of this journey ‚Äî and doing it with love, patience, and confidence in your heart. Let‚Äôs start where all good support begins ‚Äî with you. üß† When Someone You Love Says ‚ÄúI Have Cancer‚Äù There‚Äôs no easy way to hear it. Whether it was shared in a phone call, a quiet moment in the kitchen, or a blur of medical terms in a waiting room ‚Äî something in you shifted when you heard it. Your brain might have gone numb. Or started racing with fear, logistics, questions. You might‚Äôve said the ‚Äúwrong thing‚Äù or sat in silence. You might still be trying to process it. That‚Äôs okay. You‚Äôre allowed to have feelings about this, too. But here‚Äôs the thing ‚Äî in order to support someone else through this‚Ä¶ You have to ground yourself first. üåø Grounding Yourself Isn‚Äôt Selfish ‚Äî It‚Äôs Sacred When we react from fear or overwhelm, we either:
  • Try to fix everything too fast
  • Say too much, too soon
  • Or freeze and say nothing at all
That‚Äôs not your fault. It‚Äôs human. But your nervous system sets the tone. If you want to be a calming presence ‚Äî someone your loved one can lean on ‚Äî you‚Äôve got to start by coming home to your own breath. ‚ú® Try This: The ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Still Here‚Äù Breath This isn‚Äôt about meditation or doing it perfectly. It‚Äôs just a pause. A moment to return to now.
  1. Inhale slowly through your nose for 4 counts
  2. Hold for 2
  3. Exhale gently through your mouth for 6
  4. Repeat 3 times
Then say to yourself: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here. I don‚Äôt have to fix this. I just have to be present.‚Äù You can‚Äôt take the diagnosis away. But you can bring steady energy into a moment that feels like chaos. That alone is powerful. üõë What Not to Do (Right Away) It‚Äôs normal to want to jump into action, say something reassuring, or distract from the pain. But when you‚Äôre still processing, it helps to avoid these common missteps:
  • ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre going to beat this!‚Äù (sounds dismissive, even if meant with love)
  • ‚ÄúLet me know if you need anything.‚Äù (too vague, puts the burden on them)
  • ‚ÄúMy [aunt/friend/dog] had cancer and‚Ä¶‚Äù (not the time for other people‚Äôs stories)
  • ‚ÄúStay positive!‚Äù (toxic positivity shuts down real emotion)
Instead of rushing to fix or say the right thing, ask yourself: ‚ÄúWhat would I want someone to do if it were me?‚Äù Chances are, it‚Äôs less about words ‚Äî and more about presence. ‚ù§Ô∏è What Helps in the First Moments
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here with you. I love you.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to say anything right now. I‚Äôm just here.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to carry this alone. I‚Äôll walk with you through it.‚Äù
Give permission for silence. Offer steady warmth. Make your love obvious ‚Äî not through fixing, but through being. üß≠ Moving Into the Next Lesson Once you‚Äôve grounded yourself, the next question is usually: ‚ÄúOkay‚Ä¶ so what do I say now?‚Äù In Lesson 2, we‚Äôll get into what to say ‚Äî and what not to say ‚Äî when someone you love is facing cancer. We‚Äôll talk about the things people mean well with but miss the mark on, and how to communicate in a way that actually helps. But before you move on, pause. Breathe. Let the truth settle in: You are showing up. That matters. You don‚Äôt have to do this perfectly. You just have to do it with love.

item.title: First off: It‚Äôs not about being perfect. It‚Äôs about being present.
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
There‚Äôs this weird pressure to say something inspirational. To offer comfort. Or optimism. Or control. But most of the time, that pressure makes us say stuff like:
  • ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre strong! You‚Äôve got this!‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúEverything happens for a reason.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúStay positive.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúMy cousin had that and she‚Äôs totally fine now.‚Äù
It‚Äôs not wrong to want to help. But most of that stuff? It‚Äôs more about easing your discomfort than holding space for theirs. So what do you say? You say what‚Äôs real. You say what reminds them they‚Äôre not alone. You say what leaves room for their fear, their grief, their silence. Try something like:
  • ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt even know what to say right now. But I‚Äôm here.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI hate that this is happening. I‚Äôm walking with you through it.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúIf you need to scream, cry, sit in silence ‚Äî I‚Äôm here for all of it.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to be strong right now. Just be. I‚Äôve got you.‚Äù
No fixing. No pressure. Just presence. Quick tip: Avoid putting them in the position of needing to comfort you. This happens more often than people realize. You might be shocked. You might be heartbroken. But if you‚Äôre sobbing and spiraling while they‚Äôre still reeling from the diagnosis, they‚Äôll feel like they have to manage your feelings on top of their own. Instead of ‚ÄúI‚Äôm freaking out‚Äù ‚Üí try ‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling a lot, but I‚Äôve got myself. I‚Äôm focused on supporting you.‚Äù Let‚Äôs do a couple ‚Äúsay this, not that‚Äù swaps:
üö´ Don‚Äôt say this‚Ä¶ ‚úÖ Try this instead‚Ä¶
‚ÄúLet me know if you need anything.‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm free Wednesday ‚Äî can I bring dinner or run errands?‚Äù
‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got this!‚Äù ‚ÄúWhatever happens, I‚Äôm not going anywhere.‚Äù
‚ÄúJust stay positive.‚Äù ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to pretend. I‚Äôm here for the hard days too.‚Äù
‚ÄúAt least it‚Äôs not [worse type of cancer].‚Äù ‚ÄúThis sucks. I‚Äôm here for you through every part of it.‚Äù
Bottom line? Don‚Äôt try to be inspiring. Be available. Don‚Äôt try to cheerlead. Witness. Don‚Äôt try to find the silver lining. Validate their storm. It‚Äôs okay to be quiet. It‚Äôs okay to not know what to say. Just stay close. Be gentle. Keep it simple. What‚Äôs next? In the next lesson, we‚Äôre going to talk about what it actually looks like to help ‚Äî not just emotionally, but practically. Think: rides to appointments, meals, checking in without being overwhelming. Because a lot of people say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm here if you need anything,‚Äù but never follow through. We‚Äôre not going to be those people. Ready? Let‚Äôs move into the next part together. I‚Äôll meet you there.

item.title: ‚úÖ Offer Help That‚Äôs Specific and Actionable
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Here‚Äôs what that can sound like in real life:
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm heading to the store ‚Äî what can I pick up for you?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm free Thursday afternoon ‚Äî want me to drive you to your appointment?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWould it help if I dropped off dinner this weekend? I can leave it on the porch.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm walking the dog anyway ‚Äî happy to take yours with me.‚Äù
Small. Clear. Helpful. No pressure on them to figure it out. üí° Practical Ways to Show Up (Without Overcomplicating It) You don‚Äôt have to do everything. You just have to do something that meets them where they are. Here‚Äôs a short list of high-impact, low-pressure options: üç≤ Meal Support
  • Bring dinner once a week (homemade or takeout ‚Äî no judgment)
  • Organize a Meal Train or shared calendar with friends/family
  • Stock their freezer with easy-to-reheat options
üöó Errands & Appointments
  • Offer rides to treatment or doctor visits
  • Pick up prescriptions or groceries
  • Sit with them during long chemo sessions (if they want company)
üè° Home Help
  • Help with laundry or light cleaning
  • Water plants, walk the dog, tidy the kitchen
  • Do ‚Äúdrive-by‚Äù care drops (flowers, snacks, books, cozy socks)
üì± Ongoing Check-Ins
  • Text ‚Äúno pressure to reply, just thinking of you‚Äù
  • Send audio messages or memes that say ‚ÄúI see you, I love you‚Äù without requiring conversation
  • Keep checking in after the initial shock wears off ‚Äî this journey is long
üß† Pro Tip: Think rhythm, not rescue. You don‚Äôt have to swoop in and save the day. What your person really needs is consistent, calm presence. That means:
  • Showing up when you say you will
  • Sending the ‚Äújust thinking of you‚Äù text every week
  • Being the one who remembers scan day ‚Äî and checks in after
üìÖ Want to level up? Create a ‚ÄúCare Calendar.‚Äù A simple shared doc or app where people can sign up for:
  • Meal drop-offs
  • Appointment rides
  • Cleaning support
  • Childcare, pet care, errands, etc.
This helps avoid overwhelm, and ensures the support doesn‚Äôt disappear after the first couple of weeks. üõë A Quick Word About Boundaries Helping doesn‚Äôt mean burning yourself out or crossing into ‚Äúfix-it‚Äù mode. Ask: ‚ÄúHow can I help in a way that honors both their needs and my own limits?‚Äù It‚Äôs okay to say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm free Tuesday, but I can‚Äôt stay long.‚Äù It‚Äôs okay to be one part of their support team ‚Äî not the whole team. Next up‚Ä¶ So far, we‚Äôve talked about how to ground yourself, speak supportively, and offer real-world help. But what about the emotional stuff that doesn‚Äôt go away? In Lesson 4, we‚Äôll get into how to sit with the hard things:
  • What to do when treatment is scary
  • What to say when the future is unclear
  • How to stay close even when there‚Äôs nothing to fix
You don‚Äôt have to be fearless to be supportive. You just have to stay connected. And that‚Äôs where we‚Äôre headed next.

item.title: üß† There‚Äôs No Fix ‚Äî But There Is Support
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Let‚Äôs get honest: There‚Äôs nothing you can say to make chemo feel better. There‚Äôs no text that makes radiation less exhausting. There‚Äôs no affirmation that magically removes fear before a scan. But here‚Äôs the thing: They don‚Äôt need you to fix it. They just need you to stay. Sometimes the most powerful thing you can say is: ‚ÄúThis sucks. I‚Äôm here.‚Äù And then you stay. üí¨ What Showing Up Looks Like in the Middle of the Mess
  • Sitting in the waiting room without talking
  • Bringing broth, a blanket, and your quiet company
  • Texting ‚ÄúNo need to reply ‚Äî just reminding you that I love you‚Äù
  • Dropping off a little care package on treatment day
  • Watching a movie together and not talking about cancer at all
These moments? They matter. They create a sense of safety. Not because you‚Äôre saying the right thing, but because you‚Äôre not leaving. ‚ú® The Gift of Non-Answers People often try to fill the silence because silence feels uncomfortable. But when your loved one is navigating the unknown ‚Äî waiting for results, dealing with pain, thinking about scary stuff ‚Äî what they really need is space to feel it, not someone jumping in to fix it or change the subject. Here‚Äôs what works better:
  • ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay if today‚Äôs a hard day.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have to talk ‚Äî I‚Äôll just sit with you.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine how hard this is, but I‚Äôm here with you in it.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôll hold the hope today if you‚Äôre too tired to.‚Äù
üß† Protect Your Energy Without Disappearing Being present doesn‚Äôt mean you carry it all. You‚Äôre not a therapist, and you‚Äôre not the solution. You‚Äôre part of the support. So check in with yourself, too:
  • Am I showing up from love, not guilt?
  • Do I need a break to refuel, not withdraw?
  • Can I ask for help from someone else in the circle of support?
You‚Äôre allowed to step back with communication ‚Äî not disappear with silence. A simple, ‚ÄúHey, I‚Äôm thinking of you but I‚Äôm needing a recharge day. Back soon. I love you,‚Äù goes a long way. üíõ It‚Äôs Not About the Right Words ‚Äî It‚Äôs About Staying Close Let‚Äôs be real: cancer is scary. And being close to it makes people want to run. But your job isn‚Äôt to take away the pain. It‚Äôs to remind your person that they‚Äôre not alone in it. You‚Äôre the steady voice. The ride to treatment. The person who doesn‚Äôt panic when they‚Äôre having a rough day. The one who‚Äôs there when the crowd fades out. You are holding space ‚Äî and that‚Äôs sacred work. What‚Äôs next? In Lesson 5, we‚Äôll talk about what happens after treatment (or when things go into the long haul):
  • Life in remission (and the weirdness of ‚Äúgetting back to normal‚Äù)
  • Support when cancer comes back
  • Being a long-term presence, not just a crisis companion
This part is just as important. Because the support doesn‚Äôt stop when treatment ends. Let‚Äôs walk that part of the road next ‚Äî together.

item.title: üö™ When the World Moves On ‚Äî But You Don‚Äôt Want To
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Here‚Äôs the thing: when someone‚Äôs cancer treatment ‚Äúends,‚Äù the world tends to celebrate and move on. But the person who just went through it all? They might feel lost, changed, tired, scared, or unsure how to return to ‚Äúnormal.‚Äù This is where you continue to show up ‚Äî even after the casseroles and care texts stop rolling in. Here‚Äôs what that looks like:
  • ‚ÄúI know everyone‚Äôs saying ‚ÄòYay, you‚Äôre done!‚Äô but how are you really feeling?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúNo rush to be back to anything ‚Äî healing has no timeline.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still here. Let‚Äôs talk, cry, scream, or laugh ‚Äî whatever today brings.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúJust checking in. You don‚Äôt owe me a conversation ‚Äî I just love you.‚Äù
Because while everyone else is cheering the finish line, your loved one might still be in the thick of healing ‚Äî mentally, emotionally, physically. üåô Supporting the Quiet Grief Even in remission, people might deal with:
  • Fear of recurrence
  • Grief for what they lost (body changes, time, energy, fertility)
  • Identity shifts ‚Äî ‚ÄúWho am I now?‚Äù
  • Survivor‚Äôs guilt or emotional fatigue
You don‚Äôt need to fix any of it. You just need to normalize it ‚Äî and stay present through it. Let them be real with you, even if they‚Äôre no longer actively in treatment.   üåÄ When Cancer Comes Back If you‚Äôve made it this far in the course, I know this isn‚Äôt what you want to think about. But if cancer returns ‚Äî or becomes something they‚Äôll live with long-term ‚Äî the way you show up will mean everything. And the rules stay the same:
  • Don‚Äôt try to solve it
  • Don‚Äôt ghost because it‚Äôs uncomfortable
  • Don‚Äôt assume they want you to pretend everything‚Äôs fine
Instead:
  • ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still with you. Round 2 or round 10 ‚Äî I‚Äôm not going anywhere.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done hard things before. We‚Äôll do this one too.‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI love you. I‚Äôve got snacks. I‚Äôve got jokes. I‚Äôve got silence ‚Äî whatever you need.‚Äù
üíõ Being a Long-Haul Supporter You don‚Äôt have to be everything. But you can be one steady voice in their corner. Check in. Remember anniversary dates (diagnosis, surgery, last treatment). Send random ‚Äúyou‚Äôre still amazing‚Äù notes. Keep inviting them ‚Äî even if they say no. Stay flexible. Stay real. You are the reminder that love doesn‚Äôt have a timeline.   Final Words From This Course If you‚Äôve made it through all five lessons ‚Äî take a breath. You‚Äôre doing something beautiful. You‚Äôre choosing to stay close during something most people run from. You‚Äôre learning how to hold space, not just for the crisis ‚Äî but for the person. That‚Äôs rare. That‚Äôs powerful. That‚Äôs love in action. And when you need to refill your own cup, come back to this. Revisit the tools. Breathe. You‚Äôre allowed to care deeply and rest often. You don‚Äôt have to get this perfect. You just have to keep showing up. ‚Äî Want to go deeper or need help figuring out how to support someone in a more personal way? You can always reach out for 1:1 support or coaching. üìß HouseofJay@writeme.com üåê HouseofJay.net I‚Äôm proud of you. Let‚Äôs keep doing this kind of love ‚Äî the strong, steady, soft kind.   üåø Resources for Supporters & Loved Ones Whether you're at the beginning of this journey or deep in the long haul, you deserve support, too. These resources can help you stay grounded, informed, and connected as you walk alongside someone you love through cancer. üìö Books That Support the Heart & Mind
  • ‚ÄúOption B‚Äù by Sheryl Sandberg & Adam Grant For navigating grief, trauma, and supporting someone in crisis with empathy and resilience.
  • ‚ÄúBeing Mortal‚Äù by Atul Gawande A compassionate, powerful read on end-of-life care and the importance of honoring people‚Äôs choices.
  • ‚ÄúThe Art of Comforting‚Äù by Val Walker Gentle guidance on how to truly comfort people in hard seasons without trying to fix or control.
  • ‚ÄúNo Cure for Being Human‚Äù by Kate Bowler A memoir by a woman navigating cancer, faith, and the emotional contradictions of living with chronic illness.
üí¨ Online Communities & Support Spaces
  • Cancer Support Community www.cancersupportcommunity.org Free virtual and in-person support for patients, caregivers, and families.
  • CaringBridge www.caringbridge.org A simple way to coordinate care, share updates, and build a virtual support team.
  • Gilda‚Äôs Club www.gildasclub.org A nonprofit providing free support groups and resources for anyone impacted by cancer.
  • The Mighty - Cancer Support www.themighty.com Real stories, articles, and community posts from patients, survivors, and caregivers.
üß† For Mental Health & Emotional Support
  • Therapy for Caregivers Find a licensed therapist who specializes in grief, trauma, or caregiver burnout via www.psychologytoday.com
  • 7 Cups www.7cups.com Free emotional support chat and therapy options ‚Äî no pressure to speak out loud.
  • The Trevor Project (LGBTQ+ affirming crisis support) www.thetrevorproject.org 24/7 support for LGBTQ+ youth and their allies ‚Äî text, call, or chat.
  • Crisis Text Line Text HOME to 741741 ‚Äî free 24/7 support for anyone feeling overwhelmed
üìÖ Tools to Organize Care
  • Meal Train www.mealtrain.com Set up a calendar for meals, errands, and support tasks that friends can sign up for.
  • Lotsa Helping Hands www.lotsahelpinghands.com Build a care team to coordinate support with tasks, notes, and community updates.
  • Google Docs or Sheets Create a shared calendar or note system for family and friends to stay in sync.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Hi, I‚Äôm Jacquelyn ‚Äî but you can call me Jay.

I created House of Jay from a place of deep love, generational strength, and lived experience ‚Äî born not just from my own healing, but from the women who shaped me and the battles they
bravely fought.


For nearly 18 years, I struggled with PCOS and fertility challenges ‚Äî navigating years of uncertainty, frustration, and being told that maybe motherhood just wasn‚Äôt in the cards. But I refused to settle for dismissive answers.

When I discovered Functional Nutrition, everything changed. I finally understood the root causes of my symptoms, reclaimed my health, and conceived my miracle ‚Äî my moonbow baby, after the storm.

But this work ‚Äî this calling ‚Äî runs deeper than my own story.

I do this in honor of my Aunt Judy, a warrior who battled chronic illness with grace and fire. She faced rheumatoid arthritis, multiple myeloma, and later acute myeloid leukemia.

I watched her rise, rebound, and prepare for a life-saving bone marrow transplant ‚Äî only to suffer a stroke the next day. Her battle, her resilience, and her unwavering strength ignited a fire in me to explore what more we can do to support those living with chronic illness. She is the reason I started asking better questions.

And I do this for my mother, too ‚Äî who continues to show me what it means to fight. From congestive heart failure to end-stage kidney disease, I‚Äôve watched her body endure, adapt, and
rise again.

Doctors once prepared us for the worst ‚Äî but through a successful TAVR procedure and ongoing dialysis, she‚Äôs not just surviving. She‚Äôs thriving. Supporting her through that journey
became my classroom in advocacy, persistence, and the sacred role of nutrition, care, and belief.

üåø What I Do

At House of Jay, I combine functional nutrition, root cause investigation, and a trauma-aware approach to support those navigating hormone imbalances, fertility challenges, chronic illness, and burnout.

This isn‚Äôt about quick fixes or trendy protocols ‚Äî it‚Äôs about walking with you, listening to your story, and helping your body come back into balance. We rebuild from the inside out.

You deserve support that honors your full story. And at House of Jay, that‚Äôs exactly what you‚Äôll get.

üéì Credentials & Focus

  • Certified Functional Nutrition Counselor (FxNA)
  • Certified Integrative Health and Wellness Specialist
  • Specialized in PCOS, fertility, hormonal balance, chronic illness, and trauma-informed care
  • Creator of Rooted in Balance, The Testosterone Tune-Up, and Holding Space

ü§ù Let‚Äôs Connect

Whether you're reclaiming your cycle, trying to conceive, managing chronic illness, or supporting a loved one through theirs ‚Äî you don‚Äôt have to do it alone.

üñ•Ô∏è HouseofJay.net
üìß HouseofJay@writeme.com
üé• TikTok: @SomeonesMom.608
üí¨ Book a 1:1 discovery call ‚Äî and let‚Äôs walk this road together, one step at a time.

item.title: The Girl's Guide
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
The Girl's Guide

I created this guide because I know firsthand how confusing,
overwhelming, and expensive healing can feel ‚Äî especially when you‚Äôre dealing with PCOS, irregular cycles, fertility struggles, or that exhausting

energy.

The Girl's Guide to PCOS

Here‚Äôs the thing:

Healing your hormones doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect.
It doesn‚Äôt have to be expensive.
And it sure as hell doesn‚Äôt have to be boring.


What it does need to be is real, rooted in what works, and designed to fit your life ‚Äî not take it over.


That‚Äôs what this guide is about. Whether you‚Äôre here to support your cycle, prep your body for pregnancy, or just feel like yourself again, you‚Äôre in the right place. This isn‚Äôt about restriction ‚Äî it‚Äôs about reclaiming your rhythm.

PCOS on a budget:


Let‚Äôs get you nourished, educated, and empowered ‚Äî with plenty of flavor,
flexibility, and a little bit of fun (because hormones don‚Äôt have to be so serious all the time).


I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôre here. Let‚Äôs do this together.

Learn More
