item.title: PCOS on a Budget
item.dc:creator: tpetts
item.content:encoded:
Chapter 1: Budget-Friendly Food That
Fuels Hormones


Because your ovaries don‚Äôt care if it came from Whole Foods or Walmart ‚Äî they just want real nourishment.

The Myth: ‚ÄúEating Healthy Is Too Expensive‚Äù


How many times have you thought:
‚ÄúI‚Äôd eat healthier, but I can‚Äôt afford all that organic, gluten-free, dairy-free, keto whatever stuff.‚Äù


And yeah, if you‚Äôre shopping with a $16 smoothie recipe and a celebrity
wellness influencer‚Äôs pantry in mind, it will get pricey. But healing PCOS
isn‚Äôt about labels. It‚Äôs about strategy ‚Äî and blood sugar balance.


Let‚Äôs break this down:


Balancing your hormones = balancing your blood sugar + reducing
inflammation + supporting digestion.

And you can do all of that with simple, low-cost, real food.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget Rule #1: Focus on Real Food Staples


You don‚Äôt need fancy ingredients. Start with whole foods you can repurpose
across multiple meals.


ÔøΩÔøΩ Hormone-Supportive Budget Staples:

Budget Rule #2: Build a PCOS Plate for $5 or Less

Every meal should aim for 3 key elements:

  • ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Protein (eggs, chicken, lentils)
  • ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Healthy fat (avocado, olive oil, seeds)
  • ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Fiber-rich carb (sweet potatoes, quinoa, veggies)

Example: $4.85 Hormone-Loving Lunch

  • ÔÇ∑ ¬Ω cup cooked quinoa
  • ÔÇ∑ 1 cup saut√©ed kale + frozen peppers
  • ÔÇ∑ 2 scrambled eggs
  • ÔÇ∑ Topped with olive oil + hemp seeds + lemon


Simple. Balanced. Zero blood sugar crash.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget Rule #3: Batch Cook Like a Hormone Boss

Cooking a few things once can save you $ and mental energy all week.
Here‚Äôs a cheap & easy lineup to prep on Sundays:

  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Roasted sweet potatoes
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Hard-boiled eggs
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ One big hormone-friendly curry or chili (use lentils, beans, or ground turkey)
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Chopped raw veg for snacking
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ A grain: brown rice, quinoa, or oats
  • ‚ú® One batch of Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls (because snacks are self-care)

‚û° Use these as mix-and-match building blocks for breakfast bowls, quick lunches, and no-fuss dinners.

ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Smart Budget Tips for Grocery Shopping:

  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Shop the sales FIRST ‚Äî then build your meal plan around what‚Äôs affordable
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Frozen is your friend ‚Äî frozen berries, greens, cauliflower rice = nutrient-packed & cost-effective
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Bulk bins > pre-packaged ‚Äî buy seeds, spices, and oats this way to save major cash
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Store brands over name brands ‚Äî always
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Skip ‚Äúhealth halos‚Äù ‚Äî gluten-free cookies and $12 granola aren‚Äôt health foods, they‚Äôre marketing

5 Budget-Friendly Hormone-Loving Meals

  1. Chickpea Sweet Potato Stew
    ÔÇ∑ Canned chickpeas + onion + garlic + sweet potatoes + turmeric
    ÔÇ∑ Simmer with veggie broth + coconut milk
  2. Egg + Veggie Power Bowl
    ÔÇ∑ Scrambled eggs + saut√©ed spinach + brown rice + tahini drizzle
  3. Tuna Salad Wraps
    ÔÇ∑ Canned tuna + avocado + lemon + mustard + chopped celery in
    lettuce leaves
  4. One-Pot Turkey + Lentil Chili

ÔÇ∑ Ground turkey + canned lentils + tomatoes + bell peppers + spices

  1. Overnight Oats (Hormone Edition)
    ÔÇ∑ Oats + almond milk + flax seeds + cinnamon + frozen berries + scoop of protein powder

ÔøΩÔøΩ Real Talk: You Don‚Äôt Need to Be Perfect ‚Äî You Just Need to Be Consistent

You‚Äôre not failing because you didn‚Äôt buy organic.
You‚Äôre not behind because you‚Äôre making meals with $1.99 beans instead of bison liver and sea moss.
You‚Äôre resourceful. You‚Äôre learning. You‚Äôre supporting your hormones with what you‚Äôve got ‚Äî and that‚Äôs powerful AF.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Chapter 2: Supplements on a Shoestring

Because not every ‚Äúhormone hack‚Äù needs to cost $79.99 a bottle.

ÔøΩÔøΩ First: Do You Need Supplements?


Short answer? Not always.

But can the right ones support your healing? Absolutely.
The catch? You don‚Äôt need the ‚Äúinfluencer shelf‚Äù ‚Äî you need the
essentials, based on what your body actually needs. Supplements
should supplement a balanced foundation ‚Äî not replace food, sleep, or
stress care.

So let‚Äôs get into how to do this smart and on a budget.

‚úÖ Start with the Foundational 5

If you‚Äôre only going to spend money on a few things ‚Äî these are the ones that make the most bang-for-your-buck impact for PCOS:

  1. Magnesium (glycinate or citrate)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Helps with: insulin resistance, sleep, mood, cravings, PMS
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Affordable brands: NOW, Pure Encapsulations
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Dosage: 300‚Äì400mg at night
    ‚ú® Bonus: You‚Äôll probably poop better too.
  2. Vitamin D3 + K2
    • ÔøΩÔøΩ Helps with: ovulation, immune regulation, hormone signaling
    • ÔøΩÔøΩ Tip: Get your levels tested ‚Äî most PCOS babes are low
    • ÔøΩÔøΩ Dosage: 2,000‚Äì5,000 IU daily with food + fat
    • ÔøΩÔøΩ If you‚Äôre on a tight budget ‚Äî sunshine is free. 15‚Äì20 minutes a day = magic.
  3. Omega-3 (EPA/DHA)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Helps with: inflammation, egg quality, hormone production, period pain
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget buy: Costco‚Äôs fish oil, or Barlean‚Äôs Omega Swirl (on sale!)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Dosage: 1,000‚Äì2,000 mg combined EPA/DHA
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Can‚Äôt afford a supplement? Eat canned wild salmon or sardines 2x/week.
  4. Inositol (Myo or Myo + D-Chiro Blend)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Helps with: insulin resistance, ovulation, egg quality
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget brands: Wholesome Story (Amazon), BulkSupplements
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Dosage: Myo-inositol 2g twice daily (or combo blend 40:1 ratio)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Especially helpful if you have irregular periods or PCOS-related
    infertility.
  5. A Quality Multivitamin or Prenatal
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Helps with: filling nutritional gaps when food isn‚Äôt perfect
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Look for: methylated B vitamins (folate > folic acid), no fillers
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Brands under $30: Naturelo, SmartyPants, Seeking Health (often on
    sale)
    ÔøΩÔøΩ Skip anything that says ‚ÄúOne-A-Day‚Äù ‚Äî it‚Äôs underdosed and overhyped.

‚ùå What You Can (Probably) Skip

Unless your practitioner specifically tells you to, you don‚Äôt need to drop $$$ on:
ÔÇ∑ Supergreens powders
ÔÇ∑ Collagen peptides (nice, not necessary)
ÔÇ∑ DIM or estrogen blockers (can be too strong for self-dosing)
ÔÇ∑ Berberine (unless you‚Äôre under supervision ‚Äî it‚Äôs potent)
ÔÇ∑ Random hormone balancers with 15+ mystery herbs
‚ú® Reminder: More is not better. Targeted > trendy.

ÔøΩÔøΩÔ∏è Where to Buy Supplements Without Spending a Fortune

ÔøΩÔøΩ The $50 Starter Stack (For Real Ones on a Budget)


Here‚Äôs what to grab if you‚Äôre just starting out and want maximum impact
with minimal spend:

ÔøΩÔøΩ Total = ~$50 or less if you catch a sale
ÔøΩÔøΩ Pair this with food-first healing, and you‚Äôre golden.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Real Talk: If You Can‚Äôt Afford Supplements Right Now‚Ä¶

You‚Äôre not behind.
You‚Äôre not failing.
You‚Äôre still healing ‚Äî because food, movement, and nervous system
regulation are free tools that WORK.

Focus on what you can do:
ÔÇ∑ Get outside.
ÔÇ∑ Eat protein every meal.
ÔÇ∑ Walk after you eat.
ÔÇ∑ Sleep 7+ hours.
ÔÇ∑ Support your gut with whole foods and herbs.

Supplements help, but you are the real medicine.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Chapter 3: Free (or Almost Free) Healing Practices


Because some of the best PCOS treatments don‚Äôt come in a bottle ‚Äî they come in the form of consistency, calm, and conscious care.

‚ú® The Truth: You Don‚Äôt Have to Buy Your Way to Healing


Some of the most effective tools for PCOS support are things that don‚Äôt
cost anything ‚Äî they just require your time, your awareness, and your
willingness to slow down.

We‚Äôve been taught that healing comes in fancy packaging or with a high
price tag. But here‚Äôs what I want you to remember:


The things that move the needle the most ‚Äî like blood sugar balance,
stress support, and movement ‚Äî are usually free.


So let‚Äôs break down the top habits that support hormone healing without draining your bank account.

ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 1. Walking (Seriously. Just Walk.)
Forget bootcamp. Forget $180/month gyms.
Walking is one of the BEST forms of movement for PCOS.
Why it works:
ÔÇ∑ Supports insulin sensitivity
ÔÇ∑ Lowers cortisol
ÔÇ∑ Reduces inflammation
ÔÇ∑ Improves digestion and lymphatic flow
ÔÇ∑ Helps regulate appetite and mood
ÔøΩÔøΩ Try:

ÔÇ∑ A 10-minute walk after meals = blood sugar GOLD
ÔÇ∑ 20‚Äì30 minutes a day of steady, joyful movement (not punishment)
ÔÇ∑ Walk while you listen to a podcast, music, or complete silence ‚Äî
whatever feeds your nervous system

ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è 2. Nervous System Regulation
PCOS isn‚Äôt just a hormone thing ‚Äî it‚Äôs a stress thing.
When your body is constantly in ‚Äúfight or flight,‚Äù it‚Äôs going to deprioritize
things like ovulation, digestion, and hormone balance.
So we have to tell your nervous system: you‚Äôre safe now.


Free Tools That Help:
ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Box Breathing: Inhale 4, hold 4, exhale 4, hold 4
ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Cold Water Splash: On your face for vagus nerve activation
ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Humming/Singing: Yep, activates your vagus nerve
ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Grounding: Stand barefoot outside for 5‚Äì10 minutes
ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Journaling: Release what you‚Äôre holding, daily or as needed


You don‚Äôt need a meditation app. You need a quiet moment to check in with your body. That‚Äôs free.

ÔøΩÔøΩ 3. DIY Seed Cycling (Under $5 a Month)
Seed cycling is a gentle way to support estrogen and progesterone
throughout your cycle using real food.


How to Do It:
ÔÇ∑ Days 1‚Äì14 (Follicular phase): 1 tbsp flax + 1 tbsp pumpkin seeds
daily
ÔÇ∑ Days 15‚Äì28 (Luteal phase): 1 tbsp sunflower + 1 tbsp sesame
seeds daily


ÔøΩÔøΩ Buy in bulk, grind fresh if possible, store in the fridge.

Mix them into:
ÔÇ∑ Smoothies
ÔÇ∑ Oatmeal
ÔÇ∑ Yogurt bowls
ÔÇ∑ Chia pudding
ÔÇ∑ Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Balls ÔøΩÔøΩ

ÔøΩÔøΩ 4. Herbal Teas: A Budget-Friendly Wellness Hack
Teas are a super affordable way to bring in hormone support, digestive
support, and stress reduction.


Tea Faves by Goal:

‚ú® Most bulk teas cost less than $6 and last weeks.

ÔøΩÔøΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 5. Free or Low-Cost Movement
If you can‚Äôt afford a gym, that‚Äôs not a problem. YouTube is overflowing with free movement options that are PCOS-friendly.


Try:
ÔÇ∑ Yoga with Adriene (YouTube)
ÔÇ∑ Melissa Wood Health ($10/month if you want a low-cost gentle
option)

ÔÇ∑ Dance parties in your kitchen
ÔÇ∑ 10-minute stretch flows
ÔÇ∑ Bodyweight circuits at home


Remember: you‚Äôre moving to feel better, not burn calories.

ÔøΩÔøΩ 6. Track Your Cycle for Free
Understanding your cycle is essential with PCOS ‚Äî especially because it can be irregular. And while fancy hormone trackers exist, you can start with free apps or a printable calendar.


Free Tools:
ÔÇ∑ Clue or Flo app (free versions)
ÔÇ∑ Paper tracker (bonus: mindful connection)
ÔÇ∑ Free basal body temp tracking sheets
ÔÇ∑ Cervical mucus notes in your journal or app
ÔøΩÔøΩ Track for at least 2‚Äì3 months to start seeing your patterns.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Final Word: This Chapter Isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúExtra‚Äù ‚Äî It‚Äôs the Foundation
If you‚Äôre doing none of these things and only taking supplements? You‚Äôll
probably feel frustrated.
If you‚Äôre doing just these things without any supplements? You‚Äôll still make progress.
These tools are about creating a healing environment ‚Äî a body that feels safe, supported, and ready to rebalance.
And the price tag? $0‚Äì$5.


Can‚Äôt beat that.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Chapter 4: Grocery Shopping Like a PCOS Girl Boss

Because you don‚Äôt need a Whole Foods haul to eat like a hormone-healing queen.

ÔøΩÔøΩ The Vibe: Strategy > Stress


If the idea of grocery shopping for your hormones makes your eyes glaze over, trust me ‚Äî I get it. Between reading labels, decoding what‚Äôs ‚Äúhealthy,‚Äù and trying not to spend your rent money in one aisle, it can feel overwhelming.


So let‚Äôs simplify this. Shopping for PCOS doesn‚Äôt mean a cart full of kale
and kombucha. It means stocking up on real food that works for your
body ‚Äî and stretching that food across the week like the resourceful
goddess you are.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Step 1: Know the Healing Goals
We‚Äôre not just shopping for random ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù stuff. We‚Äôre shopping for
foods that support:
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Blood sugar balance
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Gut health
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Inflammation reduction
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Hormone production + detox
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Ovulation support
‚Ä¶and we‚Äôre doing it without $18 ‚Äúsuperfoods‚Äù or protein powders that taste like wet cardboard.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Step 2: Shop by Category (Not by Trend)

Here‚Äôs your core PCOS-friendly grocery list ‚Äî simple, affordable, and
easy to customize based on sales and your taste buds.


ÔøΩÔøΩ Produce
(fresh or frozen ‚Äî frozen is often cheaper and just as nutrient-rich)
ÔÇ∑ Spinach, kale, arugula
ÔÇ∑ Broccoli, cauliflower, cabbage
ÔÇ∑ Carrots, sweet potatoes, beets
ÔÇ∑ Zucchini, bell peppers, onions
ÔÇ∑ Lemons, limes, garlic, ginger
ÔÇ∑ Berries (frozen = budget-friendly magic)
ÔÇ∑ Bananas (green or slightly underripe for gut health)
ÔøΩÔøΩ Proteins
ÔÇ∑ Pasture-raised eggs (or whatever you can afford)
ÔÇ∑ Ground turkey or chicken thighs
ÔÇ∑ Canned wild salmon, sardines, or tuna
ÔÇ∑ Canned beans (chickpeas, black beans, lentils)
ÔÇ∑ Greek yogurt (plain, full-fat)
ÔÇ∑ Protein powder (optional ‚Äî go budget if you use it)
ÔøΩÔøΩ Healthy Fats
ÔÇ∑ Olive oil or avocado oil
ÔÇ∑ Nut butters (almond, sunflower seed, peanut)
ÔÇ∑ Coconut oil
ÔÇ∑ Chia, flax, pumpkin, and sunflower seeds
ÔÇ∑ Avocados (yes, get the bagged ones)
ÔøΩÔøΩ Smart Carbs + Fiber
ÔÇ∑ Brown rice or quinoa
ÔÇ∑ Gluten-free oats
ÔÇ∑ Lentils and black beans
ÔÇ∑ Cassava or almond flour (optional baking staples)
ÔÇ∑ Sweet potatoes, squash, carrots


ÔøΩÔøΩ Extras That Matter

ÔÇ∑ Apple cider vinegar
ÔÇ∑ Nutritional yeast (B vitamin love)
ÔÇ∑ Herbal teas (peppermint, ginger, raspberry leaf)
ÔÇ∑ Coconut aminos (soy sauce alternative)
ÔÇ∑ Spices: turmeric, cinnamon, cumin, garlic powder

ÔøΩÔøΩ Step 3: Budget Boss Tips (So You Don‚Äôt Overspend)

  1. Shop the sales, not the trends.
    o Base your meals around what‚Äôs affordable that week ‚Äî not
    what your feed says is ‚Äúin.‚Äù
  2. Choose frozen or canned over fresh when needed.
    o Frozen spinach, berries, cauliflower rice = budget GOLD.
  3. Skip the ‚Äúhealth halo‚Äù snacks.
    o $7 kale chips or gluten-free cookies are still processed food.
    You can DIY snacks for half the price.
  4. Pick 2‚Äì3 core meals to rotate.
    o This cuts down on food waste, decision fatigue, and cost.
  5. Buy in bulk ‚Äî but only for things you actually use.
    o Seeds, oats, lentils, and spices? Yes.
    o Random almond flour crackers? Probably not.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Step 4: Create a ‚ÄúRemixable‚Äù Grocery Plan


Here‚Äôs how to stretch your grocery haul into a full week:
Meal Base #1: Sweet potatoes + turkey + greens
ÔÇ∑ Remix as: bowls, hashes, taco filling, or salad topper
Meal Base #2: Quinoa + canned beans + veggies
ÔÇ∑ Remix as: stir-fry, burrito bowl, warm salad, soup base
Meal Base #3: Eggs + greens + whatever‚Äôs leftover

ÔÇ∑ Remix as: frittatas, breakfast burritos, scrambles

Snack Base:
ÔÇ∑ Apple + nut butter
ÔÇ∑ Yogurt + flax + berries
ÔÇ∑ Seed & Slay balls
ÔÇ∑ Veggies + hummus
ÔÇ∑ Chia pudding
‚ú® You don‚Äôt need 21 different meals for 7 days. You need a few solid
combos you actually like.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Pro Tip: Read Labels Without Getting a Headache


Keep it simple:
ÔÇ∑ Look for ingredients you can pronounce
ÔÇ∑ Skip products with added sugars, ‚Äúvegetable oils,‚Äù or mystery
flavorings
ÔÇ∑ Aim for 5 ingredients or fewer in packaged foods
If the ingredient list looks like a science experiment, put it back, bestie.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Final Word: This Is About Progress, Not Perfection
Some weeks you‚Äôll get the organic pasture-raised everything. Some weeks
you‚Äôll be grabbing canned beans and frozen spinach on sale.
Both are valid. Both are healing. Both are part of your journey.
What matters most is showing up for yourself with the resources you do
have ‚Äî not the ones you wish you had.

‚ù§Ô∏è Chapter 5: What Healing Really Looks Like (On a Budget or Not)


Because healing isn‚Äôt linear, aesthetic, or always Instagrammable ‚Äî but it‚Äôs worth every messy, magical step.

ÔøΩÔøΩ First Things First: Healing ‚â† Perfection
There‚Äôs a version of ‚Äúhealing‚Äù floating around social media that‚Äôs all yoga
mats, green smoothies, and $100 lymphatic brushes.


Here‚Äôs the real version:
ÔÇ∑ Sometimes healing is eating the eggs you can afford, not organic
pastured ones.
ÔÇ∑ Sometimes it‚Äôs skipping the workout because you chose sleep.
ÔÇ∑ Sometimes it‚Äôs crying on the kitchen floor because your period
showed up again ‚Äî but getting up anyway.
Healing isn‚Äôt perfect. It‚Äôs persistent.
And you are doing better than you think.

ÔøΩÔøΩ What Healing Actually Looks Like Over Time
Let‚Äôs get real about what to expect ‚Äî not just physically, but emotionally.

Healing is not linear. There will be flare-ups, fatigue, frustration. But there will also be breakthroughs. Lightness. And moments where you realize:
‚ÄúOh. I feel like me again.‚Äù

ÔøΩÔøΩÔ∏è Tracking Progress (Without Obsessing)


You don‚Äôt need to weigh yourself every week or track macros like a
spreadsheet. You do need ways to measure how your body is responding.


Try tracking:
ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Period frequency, flow, and symptoms
ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩÔ∏è Ovulation signs (mucus, LH strips, BBT)
ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Energy, mood, and sleep
ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Cravings and digestion
ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ What‚Äôs getting easier (stairs? sleep? saying no?)

You can use a cycle tracking app or just jot it down in a notebook. Make it simple. Make it honest.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Body Love While You Heal


This one‚Äôs important: You are allowed to love your body while still
working on it.

PCOS can mess with your confidence. Hair where you don‚Äôt want it,
periods that ghost you, weight that won‚Äôt budge ‚Äî it‚Äôs a lot.

But your body is not your enemy.
It‚Äôs not failing you.
It‚Äôs speaking to you.

What you may see as symptoms are actually signs ‚Äî and you‚Äôre learning how to read them. That‚Äôs powerful.

Start with:
ÔÇ∑ Wearing clothes that make you feel good now
ÔÇ∑ Nourishing your body with kindness, not punishment
ÔÇ∑ Saying ‚Äúthank you‚Äù for what your body can do today
You‚Äôre healing a relationship ‚Äî not just with your hormones, but with
yourself.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Building a Support Squad (On the Cheap)

You don‚Äôt need a full wellness team. But you do need support.

Free or low-cost ways to get it:
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Join online PCOS communities or subreddits
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Follow educators who teach, not just sell
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Ask your doctor for sliding scale labs or referrals
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Use community health centers for check-ins
ÔÇ∑ ‚úÖ Create a healing buddy system ‚Äî cook or check in weekly with a
friend

You‚Äôre not meant to heal alone.

ÔøΩÔøΩ Final Words: You‚Äôre Not Just Healing ‚Äî You‚Äôre Reclaiming


This guide wasn‚Äôt about quick fixes. It was about reclaiming power in a
world that‚Äôs made PCOS feel like a mystery wrapped in shame and marked ‚Äúexpensive.‚Äù

You‚Äôve learned how to:
ÔÇ∑ Eat for your hormones without going broke
ÔÇ∑ Supplement strategically
ÔÇ∑ Use free tools that support your whole body
ÔÇ∑ Grocery shop like a PCOS girl boss
ÔÇ∑ Track your progress and celebrate every win

You‚Äôve got this. Even on hard days. Especially on hard days.
Healing isn‚Äôt about doing it all.
It‚Äôs about doing what you can do with what you have ‚Äî and believing that it‚Äôs enough.


And sis‚Ä¶ it is.

You are.


ÔøΩÔøΩÔ∏è 7-Day Cheap & Chic PCOS Meal Plan

Simple, satisfying meals to nourish your hormones without wrecking your wallet.
"No gluten, no dairy, no overpriced snacks ‚Äî just real food, smart combos, and budget boss vibes."

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 1


Breakfast: Scrambled eggs with saut√©ed spinach + sweet potato hash
Snack: Apple slices with sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Chickpea + veggie stir-fry over brown rice
Snack: Chia pudding (made with almond milk + flax)
Dinner: Turkey & black bean chili (make enough for leftovers!)

ÔøΩÔøΩ Prep tip: Cook a big batch of rice and chili for Days 2‚Äì3.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 2


Breakfast: Overnight oats with frozen berries, flaxseed & cinnamon
Snack: Hard-boiled egg + cucumber slices
Lunch: Leftover turkey chili + quinoa or brown rice
Snack: Carrot sticks + hummus
Dinner: Garlic roasted sweet potatoes + steamed broccoli + a fried egg

ÔøΩÔøΩ Hack: Roast extra sweet potatoes + broccoli for future dinners.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 3


Breakfast: Chia pudding topped with banana + cinnamon
Snack: Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Ball (or DIY version!)
Lunch: Tuna salad lettuce wraps + leftover sweet potatoes
Snack: Unsweetened yogurt + flax + cinnamon
Dinner: Lentil curry with canned lentils, tomato, garlic, and frozen veggies


ÔøΩÔøΩ $ saver: Canned lentils + frozen veg = $2 meal win.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 4

Breakfast: Protein smoothie (banana, flax, oats, cinnamon, protein powder
or egg whites)
Snack: Celery + sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Quinoa + roasted veggies + tahini drizzle
Snack: Popcorn with olive oil + sea salt
Dinner: Scrambled eggs + saut√©ed kale + avocado (breakfast for dinner)


ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget bonus: Eggs = one of the cheapest high-quality proteins.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 5


Breakfast: Overnight oats with chia, almond butter + cinnamon
Snack: Hard-boiled egg + carrot sticks
Lunch: Lentil salad with cucumbers, olive oil + lemon (use leftovers!)
Snack: Apple + tahini
Dinner: Chickpea sweet potato stew with garlic, onion, and turmeric


ÔøΩÔøΩ Cook once, eat twice: Stew can stretch to lunch on Day 6.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 6


Breakfast: Fried eggs + roasted sweet potatoes + greens
Snack: Yogurt with cinnamon + chia

Lunch: Leftover chickpea stew or a simple veggie wrap
Snack: Banana + almond butter
Dinner: Zucchini stir fry with rice + scrambled egg + tamari

ÔøΩÔøΩ Budget spice swap: Use coconut aminos or low-sodium soy sauce.

ÔøΩÔøΩ DAY 7

Breakfast: Smoothie bowl (frozen berries, banana, chia, water) + seed
topping
Snack: Rice cake + sunflower seed butter
Lunch: Sweet potato & lentil mash + greens
Snack: Jay‚Äôs Seed & Slay Ball
Dinner: Sheet pan dinner: roasted carrots, broccoli, onion + baked egg or
canned salmon


ÔøΩÔøΩ Closeout tip: Use up all leftover veg in the sheet pan meal!

ÔøΩÔøΩÔ∏è Budget Grocery Staples Used:
ÔÇ∑ Eggs
ÔÇ∑ Ground turkey (or canned tuna)
ÔÇ∑ Canned beans (chickpeas, black beans, lentils)
ÔÇ∑ Sweet potatoes, carrots, onions
ÔÇ∑ Frozen spinach or broccoli
ÔÇ∑ Brown rice, oats, quinoa
ÔÇ∑ Flax, chia, cinnamon
ÔÇ∑ Olive oil, tahini or seed butter
ÔÇ∑ Bananas, apples, lemons
ÔÇ∑ Almond milk or unsweetened plant milk
ÔÇ∑ Garlic, cumin, turmeric, sea salt


Jay's Seed & Slay Balls‚Ñ¢ - Craving Control Kit

Snack your way through your cycle with Jay's Seed & Slay Balls‚Ñ¢.
These phase-based hormone bites are crafted to satisfy cravings
while nourishing your body with the ingredients it actually needs.

Each recipe supports your hormones, blood sugar, mood, and
cravings ‚Äî naturally.

ÔÇ∑ ‚ú® Follicular Phase: Glowballs


ÔÇ∑ Ingredients:

  • 1/2 cup ground flaxseed
  • 1/2 cup ground pumpkin seeds
  • 1/4 cup almond butter
  • 1 tbsp coconut oil
  • 1 tsp maca powder
  • 1/4 tsp cinnamon
  • Zest of 1 lemon
  • Optional: 1 tbsp freeze-dried raspberries or bee pollen
  • Optional: 1‚Äì2 tsp maple syrup or date syrup
    ÔÇ∑ Instructions:
    Mix all ingredients in a bowl until well combined. Roll into small bite-
    sized balls. Store in the fridge for up to 1 week or freeze for up to 1
    month.
  • ÔÇ∑ ÔøΩÔøΩ Luteal Phase: Calm & Collected Balls
    ÔÇ∑ Ingredients:
  • 1/2 cup ground sunflower seeds
  • 1/2 cup ground sesame seeds
  • 1/4 cup sunflower seed butter
  • 1 tbsp coconut oil
  • 1 tbsp raw cacao powder
  • 1/2 tsp vanilla extract
  • Pinch of sea salt
  • Optional: 1‚Äì2 chopped medjool dates or 1 tbsp chopped figs
  • Optional: cacao nibs for crunch
    ÔÇ∑ Instructions:
    Combine all ingredients in a bowl. Mix well, roll into balls, and chill.
    Store in the fridge or freezer and enjoy 1‚Äì2 daily based on your cycle
    phase.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Let's access your first mini-class!

This guide is your roadmap for smart, affordable, real-life hormone healing.
We‚Äôll cover:

  • How to grocery shop like a PCOS queen without the Whole Foods price tag
  • The supplements that actually matter ‚Äî and the ones you can skip
  • Free healing habits that support your hormones, gut, and mood
  • A sample PCOS-friendly meal plan that won‚Äôt break the bank
  • A breakdown of what healing really looks like when you're doing it on a budget

This isn‚Äôt a detox. This isn‚Äôt a diet. This is a realistic path to balance for women who are tired of being tired ‚Äî and tired of being told it‚Äôs all in their head.


You don‚Äôt need to be perfect. You don‚Äôt need to be rich.

You just need to be ready.


Ready to eat better without the overwhelm.
Ready to listen to your body without the judgment.
Ready to show up ‚Äî for your healing, for your hormones, and for yourself.


Let‚Äôs get into it.

üè° House of Jay Terms and Conditions + Disclaimer

Effective Date: 04/27/2025

1. Acceptance of Terms

By accessing, browsing, or using this website, its courses, downloads, coaching services, or any associated materials (collectively ‚ÄúServices‚Äù), you agree to be bound by these Terms and Conditions. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use the Services.

2. Educational and Informational Purposes Only

All content provided by House of Jay, including but not limited to coaching programs, guides, blog posts, videos, handouts, and downloads, is intended for educational and informational purposes only.

Nothing on this site or provided through these Services should be considered or construed as medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.
You are encouraged to consult your physician or other qualified healthcare provider before beginning any wellness, nutrition, or lifestyle program.

3. No Client-Practitioner Relationship

Participation in House of Jay Services, including but not limited to courses, free content, or newsletter subscriptions, does not automatically create a client-practitioner relationship.

A client relationship is only established through a separate formal agreement after completion of the Premier Case Review and signing of a Coaching Agreement.

4. Personal Responsibility

You acknowledge that you are voluntarily participating in the Services and that you are solely and personally responsible for your choices, actions, and results.

item.title: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Just Bloating‚Äù ‚Äî and Other Lies We‚Äôve Been Told
item.dc:creator: jfrycruz
item.content:encoded:
Let‚Äôs talk about the belly.
Not the cute, ‚ÄúI just ate a burrito‚Äù belly.
I mean the tight, uncomfortable, gassy, ‚Äúwhy do I look 6 months pregnant at 3 PM‚Äù kind of belly.
You know the one.
Maybe it‚Äôs there in the afternoon, after what seemed like a ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù lunch.
Maybe it flares with stress.
Maybe it doesn‚Äôt make sense at all ‚Äî and that‚Äôs the part that‚Äôs messing with your head.
If you‚Äôve ever been told that bloating is:
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúNormal‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúJust what happens when you eat‚Äù
‚Ä¢ ‚ÄúFixed with peppermint tea or probiotics‚Äù
...this one‚Äôs for you.
________________________________________
üß† First Things First: What Is Bloating Really?
Bloating isn‚Äôt just about having gas or being ‚Äútoo full.‚Äù
Bloating is a symptom ‚Äî a signal from your body saying:
‚ÄúHey, something‚Äôs not right here. I‚Äôm trying to deal with it, but I need some help.‚Äù
In functional nutrition, we don‚Äôt just ask how to get rid of it ‚Äî we ask:
‚Ä¢ Where is it coming from?
‚Ä¢ What system is out of balance?
‚Ä¢ What else is showing up alongside it?
Because bloating is rarely alone. It often hangs out with:
‚Ä¢ Fatigue
‚Ä¢ Constipation or loose stools
‚Ä¢ Brain fog
‚Ä¢ Hormonal imbalances
‚Ä¢ Anxiety or stress flare-ups
‚Ä¢ Skin issues or headaches
________________________________________
‚ùå Myth #1: ‚ÄúBloating Is Normal After Meals‚Äù
üßçüèΩ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Truth: A little post-meal fullness is expected ‚Äî but bloating that makes you need stretchy pants or makes you feel 6-months-pregnant by 2 PM? Not normal.
That‚Äôs a red flag for:
‚Ä¢ Low stomach acid
‚Ä¢ Slow digestion
‚Ä¢ Food sensitivities
‚Ä¢ Gut dysbiosis
‚Ä¢ Imbalanced blood sugar
Your digestive system should break food down smoothly. If it‚Äôs not, bloating is your flare gun.
________________________________________
‚ùå Myth #2: ‚ÄúYou Just Need to Drink More Water‚Äù
üö∞ Truth: Yes, dehydration can make bloating worse.
But if you‚Äôre pounding water all day and still bloated, we need to look deeper.
Functional reasons could include:
‚Ä¢ You‚Äôre not absorbing your water (electrolytes matter)
‚Ä¢ You‚Äôre constipated and water‚Äôs not moving through
‚Ä¢ You‚Äôre bloated from gut inflammation or imbalance ‚Äî and extra water is just adding volume to a system that‚Äôs already stuck
________________________________________
‚ùå Myth #3: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Just Fiber ‚Äî Your Gut Will Get Used to It‚Äù
ü•¶ Truth: Fiber can help ‚Äî but it can also make things worse if your gut isn‚Äôt ready.
If you have bloating after eating veggies, beans, or whole grains, you might have:
‚Ä¢ Low digestive enzyme output
‚Ä¢ SIBO (small intestinal bacterial overgrowth)
‚Ä¢ An inflamed or overly sensitive gut lining
We don‚Äôt force-feed fiber to a gut that‚Äôs already freaking out. We gently support digestion first ‚Äî with enzymes, cooked foods, and a slower ramp-up.
________________________________________
‚ùå Myth #4: ‚ÄúTake a Probiotic and You'll Be Fine‚Äù
üíä Truth: Probiotics are not a one-size-fits-all solution.
Some people actually get more bloated on the wrong probiotic ‚Äî especially with SIBO or histamine intolerance.
Before adding supplements, ask:
‚Ä¢ What‚Äôs the current state of my gut flora?
‚Ä¢ Am I feeding the good bugs with real food?
‚Ä¢ Do I need to reduce inflammation first?
Sometimes the best probiotic is a calming meal and a deep breath.
________________________________________
‚úÖ So‚Ä¶ What Does Help?
Here‚Äôs what we do From the Nest:
‚Ä¢ Slow down your meals. Digestion starts in the mouth ‚Äî chew, breathe, don‚Äôt rush.
‚Ä¢ Start with cooked foods. Raw can be hard on a sensitive gut.
‚Ä¢ Support your enzymes. A little apple cider vinegar or bitters pre-meal can help.
‚Ä¢ Identify trigger patterns. (Are you always bloated after eggs? After stress? After dinner?)
‚Ä¢ Balance your blood sugar. Yep ‚Äî your gut and your glucose are on the same team.
And above all: Listen to your body ‚Äî not the TikTok ‚Äúwellness‚Äù girlies who tell you bloating is sexy and normal. üôÉ
________________________________________
üíõ Final Thought:
Bloating is a messenger ‚Äî not a life sentence.
If it‚Äôs showing up every day, you don‚Äôt need to mask it.
You need someone to help you understand it.
And that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm here for.
So if you‚Äôre bloated, frustrated, and tired of guessing ‚Äî see things From the Nest. You‚Äôre not crazy. You‚Äôre not broken.
You just need a new way to listen.
Until next time,
Jay üê¶
